					<h1 id="section_0">Apple Inc.</h1>
					<div class="tagline"></div>

			<div id="bodyContent" class="content"><div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><script>function mfTempOpenSection(id){var block=document.getElementById("mf-section-"+id);block.className+=" open-block";block.previousSibling.className+=" open-block";}</script><div class="mw-parser-output"><section class="mf-section-0" id="mf-section-0"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Apple (company)" redirects here. For other companies of similar name, see <a href="/wiki/Apple_(disambiguation)#Brands_and_enterprises" class="mw-disambig" title="Apple (disambiguation)">Apple (disambiguation)  § Brands and enterprises</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<p>

<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Apple_Inc.&amp;params=37.3349_N_122.009_W_region:US-CA"><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">37°20′06″N</span> <span class="longitude">122°00′32″W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">37.3349°N 122.0090°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">37.3349; -122.0090</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>
<p><b>Apple Inc.</b> is an American <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational</a> <a href="/wiki/Technology_company" title="Technology company">technology company</a> headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Cupertino,_California" title="Cupertino, California">Cupertino, California</a>, that designs, develops, and sells <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software" title="Software">computer software</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Online_services" class="mw-redirect" title="Online services">online services</a>. It is considered one of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_tech_companies" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Four tech companies">Big Four</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization" title="List of public corporations by market capitalization">technology companies</a>, alongside <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup></p><table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><caption class="fn org">Apple Inc.</caption><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" class="logo" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_logo_black.svg" class="image"><img alt="Apple logo black.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/80px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png" decoding="async" width="80" height="95" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/120px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/160px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1187"></a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="logo" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Apple park cupertino 2019.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg/260px-Apple_park_cupertino_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="146" data-file-width="5464" data-file-height="3070"></a><div>Overhead view of <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">Apple Park</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Cupertino,_California" title="Cupertino, California">Cupertino, id="cite_ref-SEC_filing_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_filing-1">[1]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Earnings_before_interest_and_taxes" title="Earnings before interest and taxes">Operating income</a></div></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><img alt="Decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300"> <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$63.930 billion</span><sup id="cite_ref-SEC_filing_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_filing-1">[1]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;"><a href="/wiki/Net_income" title="Net income">Net income</a></div></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><img alt="Decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300"> <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$55.256 billion</span><sup id="cite_ref-SEC_filing_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_filing-1">[1]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Asset" title="Asset">Total assets</a></span></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><img alt="Decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300"> <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$338.516 billion</span><sup id="cite_ref-SEC_filing_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_filing-1">[1]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Equity_(finance)" title="Equity (finance)">Total equity</a></span></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><img alt="Decrease" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/11px-Decrease2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Decrease" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/17px-Decrease2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Decrease2.svg/22px-Decrease2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300"> <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$90.488 billion</span><sup id="cite_ref-SEC_filing_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_filing-1">[1]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">Number of employees</div></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;">137,000<sup id="cite_ref-SEC_10-K_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SEC_10-K-2">[2]</a></sup> (2019)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;"><a href="/wiki/Subsidiary" title="Subsidiary">Subsidiaries</a></th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Braeburn_Capital" title="Braeburn Capital">Braeburn Capital</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Beats_Electronics" title="Beats Electronics">Beats Electronics</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Claris" title="Claris">Claris</a></li><li>Apple Energy, LLC</li><li>Apple Sales International<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></li><li>Apple Services<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup></li><li>Apple Worldwide Video<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup></li><li><a href="/wiki/Anobit" title="Anobit">Anobit</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Beddit" title="Beddit">Beddit</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="padding-right: 0.5em;">Website</th><td style="line-height: 1.35em;"><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.apple.com">www<wbr></wbr>.apple<wbr></wbr>.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table><p>The company's <a href="/wiki/Computer_hardware" title="Computer hardware">hardware</a> products include the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> smartphone, the <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a> tablet computer, the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh" title="Macintosh">Mac</a> personal computer, the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> portable media player, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a> smartwatch, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a> digital media player, the <a href="/wiki/AirPods" title="AirPods">AirPods</a> wireless earbuds and the <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a> smart speaker. Apple's software includes the <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPadOS" title="IPadOS">iPadOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/WatchOS" title="WatchOS">watchOS</a>, and <a href="/wiki/TvOS" title="TvOS">tvOS</a> operating systems, the <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a> media player, the <a href="/wiki/Safari_(web_browser)" title="Safari (web browser)">Safari</a> web browser, the <a href="/wiki/Shazam_(application)" title="Shazam (application)">Shazam</a> acoustic fingerprint utility, and the <a href="/wiki/ILife" title="ILife">iLife</a> and <a href="/wiki/IWork" title="IWork">iWork</a> creativity and productivity suites, as well as professional applications like <a href="/wiki/Final_Cut_Pro" title="Final Cut Pro">Final Cut Pro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Logic_Pro" title="Logic Pro">Logic Pro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Xcode" title="Xcode">Xcode</a>. Its online services include the <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a>, the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">iOS App Store</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mac_App_Store" class="mw-redirect" title="Mac App Store">Mac App Store</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV%2B" title="Apple TV+">Apple TV+</a>, <a href="/wiki/IMessage" title="IMessage">iMessage</a>, and <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>. Other services include <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genius_Bar" title="Genius Bar">Genius Bar</a>, <a href="/wiki/AppleCare" title="AppleCare">AppleCare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Pay" title="Apple Pay">Apple Pay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Pay_Cash" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Pay Cash">Apple Pay Cash</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Card" title="Apple Card">Apple Card</a>.
</p><p>Apple was founded by <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Wayne" title="Ronald Wayne">Ronald Wayne</a> in April 1976 to develop and sell Wozniak's <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a> personal computer, though Wayne sold his share back within 12 days. It was incorporated as <b>Apple Computer, Inc.</b>, in January 1977, and sales of its computers, including the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">Apple II</a>, grew quickly. Within a few years, Jobs and Wozniak had hired a staff of computer designers and had a production line. Apple <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">went public</a> in 1980 to instant financial success. Over the next few years, Apple shipped new computers featuring innovative <a href="/wiki/Graphical_user_interface" title="Graphical user interface">graphical user interfaces</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128K" title="Macintosh 128K">original Macintosh</a> in 1984, and Apple's marketing advertisements for its products received widespread critical acclaim. However, the high price of its products and limited application library caused problems, as did power struggles between executives. In 1985, Wozniak departed Apple amicably and remained an honorary employee,<sup id="cite_ref-wozemployee_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozemployee-9">[9]</a></sup> while Jobs and others resigned to found <a href="/wiki/NeXT" title="NeXT">NeXT</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rice19850415_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice19850415-10">[10]</a></sup></p><p>As the market for personal computers expanded and evolved through the 1990s, Apple lost market share to the lower-priced duopoly of <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a> on <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> PC clones. The board recruited <a href="/wiki/CEO" class="mw-redirect" title="CEO">CEO</a> <a href="/wiki/Gil_Amelio" title="Gil Amelio">Gil Amelio</a> to what would be a 500-day charge for him to rehabilitate the financially troubled company—reshaping it with layoffs, executive restructuring, and product focus. In 1997, he led Apple to buy NeXT, solving the desperately failed operating system strategy and bringing Jobs back. Jobs pensively regained leadership status, becoming CEO in 2000. Apple swiftly returned to profitability under the revitalizing <a href="/wiki/Think_different" title="Think different">Think different</a> campaign, as he rebuilt Apple's status by launching the <a href="/wiki/IMac_G3" title="IMac G3">iMac</a> in 1998, opening the retail chain of <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Stores</a> in 2001, and acquiring numerous companies to broaden the software portfolio. In January 2007, Jobs renamed the company Apple Inc., reflecting its shifted focus toward consumer electronics, and launched the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> to great critical acclaim and financial success. In August 2011, Jobs resigned as CEO due to health complications, and <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> became the new CEO. Two months later, Jobs died, marking the end of an era for the company. In June 2019, <a href="/wiki/Jony_Ive" title="Jony Ive">Jony Ive</a>, Apple's <a href="/wiki/Chief_design_officer" title="Chief design officer">CDO</a>, left the company to start his own firm but stated he would work with Apple as its primary client.
</p><p>Apple is well known for its size and revenues. Its worldwide annual revenue totaled $265 billion for the 2018 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a>. Apple is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_information_technology_companies" class="mw-redirect" title="List of the largest information technology companies">world's largest technology company</a> by revenue and one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization" title="List of public corporations by market capitalization">world's most valuable companies</a>. It is also the world's third-largest mobile phone manufacturer after <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> In August 2018, Apple became the first public U.S. company to be valued at over $1 trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-1t-CNBC_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-CNBC-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1t-Guardian_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-Guardian-13">[13]</a></sup> The company employs 123,000 full-time employees<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-Inc-Nov-2017-10-K_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-Inc-Nov-2017-10-K-14">[14]</a></sup> and maintains 504 <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">retail stores</a> in 24 countries as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> It operates the iTunes Store, which is the world's largest music retailer. As of January 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, more than 1.3 billion Apple products are actively in use worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> The company also has a high level of <a href="/wiki/Brand_loyalty" title="Brand loyalty">brand loyalty</a> and is ranked as the world's most valuable brand. However, Apple <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Apple_Inc." title="Criticism of Apple Inc.">receives significant criticism</a> regarding the labor practices of its contractors, its environmental practices and unethical business practices, including <a href="/wiki/Anti-competitive_practices" title="Anti-competitive practices">anti-competitive behavior</a>, as well as the origins of source materials.
</p>

</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(1)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2><section class="mf-section-1 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-1">
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Apple_Inc." title="History of Apple Inc.">History of Apple Inc.</a></div>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="1976.E2.80.931984:_Founding_and_incorporation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1976–1984:_Founding_and_incorporation">1976–1984: Founding and incorporation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Apple#1975%E2%80%931985:_Jobs_and_Wozniak" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Apple">History of Apple § 1975–1985: Jobs and Wozniak</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Garage.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/220px-Apple_Garage.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 147px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/220px-Apple_Garage.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="147" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Garage.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1976, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> co-founded Apple in his parents' home on Crist Drive in <a href="/wiki/Los_Altos,_California" title="Los Altos, California">Los Altos, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046%E2%80%938-17">[17]</a></sup> Although it is widely believed that the company was founded in the house's garage, Apple co-founder <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a> called it "a bit of a myth".<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Jobs and Wozniak did, however, move some operations to the garage when the bedroom became too crowded.<sup id="cite_ref-Linzmayer01_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Linzmayer01-19">[19]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_I_Computer.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Apple_I_Computer.jpg/220px-Apple_I_Computer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="2833" data-file-height="1720"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 134px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Apple_I_Computer.jpg/220px-Apple_I_Computer.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="134" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_I_Computer.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Apple's first product, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a>, invented by Steve Wozniak, was sold as an assembled circuit board and lacked basic features such as a keyboard, monitor, and case. The owner of this unit added a keyboard and wooden case.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_II_Plus,_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg/220px-Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2588"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 146px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg/220px-Apple_II_Plus%2C_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="146" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_II_Plus,_Museum_of_the_Moving_Image.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Apple_II_Plus" title="Apple II Plus">Apple II Plus</a>, introduced in 1979, designed primarily by Wozniak</div></div></div>
<p>Apple Computer Company was founded on April 1, 1976, by <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Wayne" title="Ronald Wayne">Ronald Wayne</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Business_partnership" class="mw-redirect" title="Business partnership">business partnership</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046%E2%80%938-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> The company's first product was the <a href="/wiki/Apple_I" title="Apple I">Apple I</a>, a computer designed and hand-built entirely by Wozniak,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> and first shown to the public at the <a href="/wiki/Homebrew_Computer_Club" title="Homebrew Computer Club">Homebrew Computer Club</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20092–3_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20092%E2%80%933-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Apple I was sold as a <a href="/wiki/Motherboard" title="Motherboard">motherboard</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Central_processing_unit" title="Central processing unit">CPU</a>, <a href="/wiki/Random-access_memory" title="Random-access memory">RAM</a>, and basic textual-video chips)—a base kit concept which would now not be marketed as a complete personal computer.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The Apple I went on sale in July 1976 and was market-priced at $666.66 ($2,995 in 2019 dollars, adjusted for inflation).<sup id="cite_ref-inflation-US_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-inflation-US-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iWoz_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iWoz-31">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>180</span></sup> Wozniak later said he had no idea about the relation between the number and the <a href="/wiki/Mark_of_the_beast" class="mw-redirect" title="Mark of the beast">mark of the beast</a>, and that he came up with the price because he liked "repeating digits".<sup id="cite_ref-VintageNews_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VintageNews-32">[32]</a></sup></p><p>Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200410_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200410-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Apple_FAQ_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-34">[34]</a></sup> without Wayne, who had left and sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 only twelve days after having co-founded Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Multimillionaire <a href="/wiki/Mike_Markkula" title="Mike Markkula">Mike Markkula</a> provided essential business expertise and funding of $250,000 during the incorporation of Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> During the first five years of operations, revenues grew exponentially, doubling about every four months. Between September 1977 and September 1980, yearly sales grew from $775,000 to $118 million, an average annual growth rate of 533%.<sup id="cite_ref-Infinite_Loop_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Infinite_Loop-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup></p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Apple_II_series" title="Apple II series">Apple II</a>, also invented by Wozniak, was introduced on April 16, 1977, at the first <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Computer_Faire" title="West Coast Computer Faire">West Coast Computer Faire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200412_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200412-41">[41]</a></sup> It differs from its major rivals, the <a href="/wiki/TRS-80" title="TRS-80">TRS-80</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commodore_PET" title="Commodore PET">Commodore PET</a>, because of its character cell-based color graphics and <a href="/wiki/Open_architecture" title="Open architecture">open architecture</a>. While early Apple II models use ordinary cassette tapes as storage devices, they were superseded by the introduction of a ​<span class="frac nowrap">5<span class="visualhide"> </span><sup>1</sup>⁄<sub>4</sub></span>-inch <a href="/wiki/Floppy_disk" title="Floppy disk">floppy disk</a> drive and interface called the <a href="/wiki/Disk_II" title="Disk II">Disk II</a> in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413%E2%80%9315-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> The Apple II was chosen to be the desktop platform for the first "<a href="/wiki/Killer_application" title="Killer application">killer application</a>" of the business world: <a href="/wiki/VisiCalc" title="VisiCalc">VisiCalc</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Spreadsheet" title="Spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a> <a href="/wiki/Computer_program" title="Computer program">program</a> released in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413%E2%80%9315-42">[42]</a></sup> VisiCalc created a business market for the Apple II and gave home users an additional reason to buy an Apple II: compatibility with the office.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413%E2%80%9315-42">[42]</a></sup> Before VisiCalc, Apple had been a distant third place competitor to <a href="/wiki/Commodore_64" title="Commodore 64">Commodore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tandy_Computers" class="mw-redirect" title="Tandy Computers">Tandy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup></p><p>By the end of the 1970s, Apple had a staff of computer designers and a production line. The company introduced the <a href="/wiki/Apple_III" title="Apple III">Apple III</a> in May 1980 in an attempt to compete with <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a> in the business and corporate computing market.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20096_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20096-46">[46]</a></sup> Jobs and several Apple employees, including <a href="/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interface" class="mw-redirect" title="Human–computer interface">human–computer interface</a> expert <a href="/wiki/Jef_Raskin" title="Jef Raskin">Jef Raskin</a>, visited <a href="/wiki/PARC_(company)" title="PARC (company)">Xerox PARC</a> in December 1979 to see a demonstration of the <a href="/wiki/Xerox_Alto" title="Xerox Alto">Xerox Alto</a>. <a href="/wiki/Xerox" title="Xerox">Xerox</a> granted Apple engineers three days of access to the PARC facilities in return for the option to buy 100,000<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> shares (5.6 million <a href="/wiki/Split-adjusted" class="mw-redirect" title="Split-adjusted">split-adjusted</a> shares as of March 30, 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>)<sup id="cite_ref-Apple_FAQ_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-34">[34]</a></sup> of Apple at the pre-IPO price of $10 a share.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup></p><p>Jobs was immediately convinced that all future computers would use a graphical user interface (<a href="/wiki/Graphical_user_interface" title="Graphical user interface">GUI</a>), and development of a GUI began for the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Lisa" title="Apple Lisa">Apple Lisa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> In 1982, however, he was pushed from the Lisa team due to infighting. Jobs then took over Wozniak's and Raskin's low-cost-computer project, the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh" title="Macintosh">Macintosh</a>, and redefined it as a graphical system cheaper and faster than Lisa.<sup id="cite_ref-TheVerge_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheVerge-50">[50]</a></sup> In 1983, Lisa became the first personal computer sold to the public with a GUI, but was a commercial failure due to its high price and limited software titles, so in 1985 it would be repurposed as the high end Macintosh and discontinued in its second year.<sup id="cite_ref-lemlisa_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemlisa-51">[51]</a></sup></p><p>On December 12, 1980, Apple (ticker symbol "AAPL") went public selling 4.6 million shares at $22 per share ($.39 per share when adjusting for <a href="/wiki/Stock_split" title="Stock split">stock splits</a> as of March 30, 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>),<sup id="cite_ref-Apple_FAQ_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-34">[34]</a></sup> generating over $100 million, which was more capital than any IPO since <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford Motor Company</a> in 1956.<sup id="cite_ref-EDNAAPLSTOCK_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-52">[52]</a></sup> By the end of the day, the stock rose to $29 per share and 300 millionaires were created.<sup id="cite_ref-DEDIPO_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEDIPO-53">[53]</a></sup> Apple's market cap was $1.778 billion at the end of its first day of trading.<sup id="cite_ref-EDNAAPLSTOCK_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DEDIPO_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEDIPO-53">[53]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="1984.E2.80.931991:_Success_with_Macintosh"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1984–1991:_Success_with_Macintosh">1984–1991: Success with Macintosh</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Macintosh_models" title="Timeline of Macintosh models">Timeline of Macintosh models</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Apple_II_family" title="Timeline of the Apple II family">Timeline of the Apple II family</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Macintosh,_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/220px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="865" data-file-height="615"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 156px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/220px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="156" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Macintosh,_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128k" class="mw-redirect" title="Macintosh 128k">Macintosh</a>, released in 1984, is the first mass-market personal computer to feature an integral graphical user interface and mouse.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1984, Apple launched the Macintosh, the first personal computer to be sold without a <a href="/wiki/Programming_language" title="Programming language">programming language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IsProgramingObsolete_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IsProgramingObsolete-54">[54]</a></sup> Its debut was signified by <a href="/wiki/1984_(advertisement)" title="1984 (advertisement)">"1984"</a>, a $1.5 million television advertisement directed by <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a> that aired during the third quarter of <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XVIII" title="Super Bowl XVIII">Super Bowl XVIII</a> on January 22, 1984.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> This is now hailed as a watershed event for Apple's success<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> and was called a "masterpiece" by <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> and one of the greatest TV advertisements of all time by <i><a href="/wiki/TV_Guide" title="TV Guide">TV Guide</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup></p><p>Macintosh sales were initially good, but began to taper off dramatically after the first three months due to its high price, slow speed, and limited range of available software.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200498_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200498-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESwaine2014441–443_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwaine2014441%E2%80%93443-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>195</span></sup> In early 1985, this sales slump triggered a power struggle between Steve Jobs and CEO <a href="/wiki/John_Sculley" title="John Sculley">John Sculley</a>, who had been hired two years earlier by Jobs<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015153–154_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015153%E2%80%93154-65">[65]</a></sup> using the famous line, "Do you want to sell sugar water for the rest of your life or come with me and change the world?"<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Sculley decided to remove Jobs as the general manager of the Macintosh division, and gained unanimous support from the Apple board of directors.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156-64">[64]</a></sup></p><p>The board of directors instructed Sculley to contain Jobs and his ability to launch expensive forays into untested products. Rather than submit to Sculley's direction, Jobs attempted to oust him from his leadership role at Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156%E2%80%93157-68">[68]</a></sup> Informed by <a href="/wiki/Jean-Louis_Gass%C3%A9e" title="Jean-Louis Gassée">Jean-Louis Gassée</a>, Sculley found out that Jobs had been attempting to organize a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat#Other_uses_of_the_term" title="Coup d'état">coup</a> and called an emergency executive meeting at which Apple's executive staff sided with Sculley and stripped Jobs of all operational duties.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156%E2%80%93157-68">[68]</a></sup> Jobs resigned from Apple in September 1985 and took a number of Apple employees with him to found <a href="/wiki/NeXT" title="NeXT">NeXT Inc.</a><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Wozniak had also quit his active employment at Apple earlier in 1985 to pursue other ventures, expressing his frustration with Apple's treatment of the Apple II division and stating that the company had "been going in the wrong direction for the last five years".<sup id="cite_ref-rice19850415_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rice19850415-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wozemployee_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozemployee-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Despite Wozniak's grievances, he left the company amicably and both Jobs and Wozniak remained Apple shareholders.<sup id="cite_ref-wozstock_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozstock-71">[71]</a></sup> Wozniak continues to represent the company at events or in interviews,<sup id="cite_ref-wozemployee_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozemployee-9">[9]</a></sup> receiving a stipend estimated to be $120,000 per year for this role.<sup id="cite_ref-iWoz_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iWoz-31">[31]</a></sup></p><p>The outlook on Macintosh improved with the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/LaserWriter" title="LaserWriter">LaserWriter</a>, the first reasonably priced <a href="/wiki/PostScript" title="PostScript">PostScript</a> <a href="/wiki/Laser_printer" class="mw-redirect" title="Laser printer">laser printer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Adobe_PageMaker" title="Adobe PageMaker">PageMaker</a>, an early <a href="/wiki/Desktop_publishing" title="Desktop publishing">desktop publishing</a> application released in July 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004158–159_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004158%E2%80%93159-72">[72]</a></sup> It has been suggested that the combination of Macintosh, LaserWriter, and PageMaker was responsible for the creation of the desktop publishing market.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (July 2019)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Macintosh_portable.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Macintosh_portable.jpg/220px-Macintosh_portable.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="184" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="573" data-file-height="480"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 184px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Macintosh_portable.jpg/220px-Macintosh_portable.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="184" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Macintosh_portable.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Portable" title="Macintosh Portable">Macintosh Portable</a>, released in 1989, is Apple's first battery-powered portable Macintosh personal computer.</div></div></div>
<p>After the departures of Jobs and Wozniak, the Macintosh product line underwent a steady change of focus to higher price points, the so-called "high-right policy" named for the position on a chart of price vs. profits. Jobs had argued the company should produce products aimed at the consumer market and aimed for a $1,000 price for the Macintosh, which they were unable to meet. Newer models selling at higher price points offered higher <a href="/wiki/Profit_margin" title="Profit margin">profit margin</a>, and appeared to have no effect on total sales as <a href="/wiki/Power_user" title="Power user">power users</a> snapped up every increase in power. Although some worried about pricing themselves out of the market, the high-right policy was in full force by the mid-1980s, notably due to Jean-Louis Gassée's mantra of "fifty-five or die", referring to the 55% <a href="/wiki/Profit_margin" title="Profit margin">profit margins</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_II" title="Macintosh II">Macintosh II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-insidestoryCarlton_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insidestoryCarlton-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>79–80</span></sup> Selling Macintosh at such high profit margins was only possible because of its dominant position in the desktop publishing market.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup></p><p>This policy began to backfire in the last years of the decade as new desktop publishing programs appeared on <a href="/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible" title="IBM PC compatible">PC clones</a> that offered some or much of the same functionality of the Macintosh but at far lower price points. The company lost its monopoly in this market and had already estranged many of its original consumer customer base who could no longer afford their high-priced products. The Christmas season of 1989 is the first in the company's history to have declining sales, which led to a 20% drop in Apple's stock price.<sup id="cite_ref-insidestoryCarlton_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-insidestoryCarlton-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>117–129</span></sup> During this period, the relationship between Sculley and Gassée deteriorated, leading Sculley to effectively demote Gassée in January 1990 by appointing <a href="/wiki/Michael_Spindler" title="Michael Spindler">Michael Spindler</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Chief_operating_officer" title="Chief operating officer">chief operating officer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004184–185_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004184%E2%80%93185-76">[76]</a></sup> Gassée left the company later that year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004160_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004160-77">[77]</a></sup> In October 1990, Apple introduced three lower-cost models, the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Classic" title="Macintosh Classic">Macintosh Classic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_LC" title="Macintosh LC">Macintosh LC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_IIsi" title="Macintosh IIsi">Macintosh IIsi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004128_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004128-78">[78]</a></sup> all of which saw significant sales due to pent-up demand.
</p><p>In 1991, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/PowerBook" title="PowerBook">PowerBook</a>, replacing the "luggable" <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Portable" title="Macintosh Portable">Macintosh Portable</a> with a design that set the current shape for almost all modern laptops. The same year, Apple introduced <a href="/wiki/System_7" title="System 7">System 7</a>, a major upgrade to the operating system which added color to the interface and introduced new networking capabilities. It remained the architectural basis for the <a href="/wiki/Classic_Mac_OS" title="Classic Mac OS">Classic Mac OS</a>. The success of the PowerBook and other products brought increasing revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-lemsculley_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemsculley-79">[79]</a></sup> For some time, Apple was doing incredibly well, introducing fresh new products and generating increasing profits in the process. The magazine <i><a href="/wiki/MacAddict" class="mw-redirect" title="MacAddict">MacAddict</a></i> named the period between 1989 and 1991 as the "first golden age" of the Macintosh.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup></p><p>Apple believed the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II_series" title="Apple II series">Apple II series</a> was too expensive to produce and took away sales from the low-end Macintosh.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> In October 1990, Apple released the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_LC" title="Macintosh LC">Macintosh LC</a>, and began efforts to promote that computer by advising developer technical support staff to recommend developing applications for Macintosh rather than Apple II, and authorizing salespersons to direct consumers towards Macintosh and away from Apple II.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Apple_IIe" title="Apple IIe">Apple IIe</a> was discontinued in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="1991.E2.80.931997:_Decline_and_restructuring"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1991–1997:_Decline_and_restructuring">1991–1997: Decline and restructuring</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Apple_II_family" title="Timeline of the Apple II family">Timeline of the Apple II family</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_PenLite_prototype,_1992.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg/220px-Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="3823" data-file-height="2321"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 134px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg/220px-Apple_PenLite_prototype%2C_1992.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="134" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_PenLite_prototype,_1992.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Penlite is Apple's first prototype of a tablet computer. Created in 1992, the project was designed to bring the Mac OS to a tablet – but was canceled in favor of the <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The success of Apple's lower-cost consumer models, especially the LC, also led to the cannibalization of their higher-priced machines. To address this, management introduced several new brands, selling largely identical machines at different price points aimed at different markets. These were the high-end <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Quadra" title="Macintosh Quadra">Quadra</a>, the mid-range <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Centris" title="Macintosh Centris">Centris</a> line, and the consumer-marketed <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Performa" title="Macintosh Performa">Performa</a> series. This led to significant market confusion, as customers did not understand the difference between models.<sup id="cite_ref-vawperforma_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vawperforma-85">[85]</a></sup></p><p>Apple also experimented with a number of other unsuccessful consumer targeted products during the 1990s, including <a href="/wiki/Apple_QuickTake" title="Apple QuickTake">digital cameras</a>, <a href="/wiki/PowerCD" title="PowerCD">portable CD audio players</a>, <a href="/wiki/AppleDesign_Powered_Speakers" class="mw-redirect" title="AppleDesign Powered Speakers">speakers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Bandai_Pippin" title="Apple Bandai Pippin">video consoles</a>, the <a href="/wiki/EWorld" title="EWorld">eWorld</a> online service, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Interactive_Television_Box" title="Apple Interactive Television Box">TV appliances</a>. Enormous resources were also invested in the problem-plagued <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton division</a> based on John Sculley's unrealistic market forecasts.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Ultimately, none of these products helped and Apple's market share and stock prices continued to slide.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p><p>Throughout this period, Microsoft continued to gain market share with <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Windows</a> by focusing on delivering software to cheap commodity personal computers, while Apple was delivering a richly engineered but expensive experience.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Apple relied on high profit margins and never developed a clear response; instead, they sued Microsoft for using a GUI similar to the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Lisa" title="Apple Lisa">Apple Lisa</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_Computer,_Inc._v._Microsoft_Corp." title="Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp.">Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp.</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-lemms_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemms-87">[87]</a></sup> The lawsuit dragged on for years before it was finally dismissed. At this time, a series of major product flops and missed deadlines sullied Apple's reputation, and Sculley was replaced as CEO by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Spindler" title="Michael Spindler">Michael Spindler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG/220px-Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="189" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="2382" data-file-height="2048"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 189px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG/220px-Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="189" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Newton-IMG_0320_cleanup.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a> is Apple's first <a href="/wiki/Personal_digital_assistant" title="Personal digital assistant">PDA</a> brought to market, as well as one of the first in the industry. Though failing financially at the time of its release, it helped pave the way for the <a href="/wiki/PalmPilot" title="PalmPilot">PalmPilot</a> and Apple's own <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a> in the future.</div></div></div>
<p>By the late 1980s, Apple was developing alternative platforms to System 6, such as <a href="/wiki/A/UX" title="A/UX">A/UX</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taligent#Pink" title="Taligent">Pink</a>. The System 6 platform itself was outdated because it was not originally built for multitasking. By the 1990s, Apple was facing competition from <a href="/wiki/OS/2" title="OS/2">OS/2</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNIX" class="mw-redirect" title="UNIX">UNIX</a> vendors such as <a href="/wiki/Sun_Microsystems" title="Sun Microsystems">Sun Microsystems</a>. System 6 and 7 would need to be replaced by a new platform or reworked to run on modern hardware.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup></p><p>In 1994, Apple, <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/AIM_alliance" title="AIM alliance">AIM alliance</a> with the goal of creating a new computing platform (the <a href="/wiki/PowerPC_Reference_Platform" title="PowerPC Reference Platform">PowerPC Reference Platform</a>), which would use IBM and Motorola hardware coupled with Apple software. The AIM alliance hoped that PReP's performance and Apple's software would leave the PC far behind and thus counter Microsoft's monopoly. The same year, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh" title="Power Macintosh">Power Macintosh</a>, the first of many Apple computers to use Motorola's <a href="/wiki/PowerPC" title="PowerPC">PowerPC</a> processor.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup></p><p>In 1996, Spindler was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Gil_Amelio" title="Gil Amelio">Gil Amelio</a> as CEO. Hired for his reputation as a corporate rehabilitator, Amelio made deep changes, including extensive layoffs and cost-cutting.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> After numerous failed attempts to modernize Mac OS, first with the <a href="/wiki/Taligent" title="Taligent">Pink</a> project from 1988 and later with <a href="/wiki/Copland_(operating_system)" title="Copland (operating system)">Copland</a> from 1994, Apple in 1997 purchased <a href="/wiki/NeXT" title="NeXT">NeXT</a> for its <a href="/wiki/NeXTSTEP" title="NeXTSTEP">NeXTSTEP</a> operating system and to bring Steve Jobs back.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Apple was only weeks away from <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">bankruptcy</a> when Jobs returned.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="1997.E2.80.932007:_Return_to_profitability"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1997–2007:_Return_to_profitability">1997–2007: Return to profitability</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r923042769/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption-center{text-align:center;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_02.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_02.jpg/200px-Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="239" data-file-width="3090" data-file-height="3698"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 200px;height: 239px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_02.jpg/200px-Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_02.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="200" data-height="239"> </span></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_01.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_01.jpg/200px-Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="239" data-file-width="3090" data-file-height="3698"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 200px;height: 239px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_01.jpg/200px-Apple_Power_Macintosh_G5_Late_2005_01.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="200" data-height="239"> </span></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh" title="Power Macintosh">Power Macintosh</a> is a line of Apple Macintosh <a href="/wiki/Workstation" title="Workstation">workstation-class</a> personal computers based on various models of <a href="/wiki/PowerPC" title="PowerPC">PowerPC</a> microprocessors, that were developed from 1994 to 2006.</div></div></div></div>
<p>The NeXT acquisition was finalized on February 9, 1997,<sup id="cite_ref-archive_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-archive-94">[94]</a></sup> bringing Jobs back to Apple as an advisor. On July 9, 1997, Amelio was ousted by the board of directors after overseeing a three-year record-low stock price and crippling financial losses. Jobs acted as the interim CEO and began restructuring the company's product line; it was during this period that he identified the design talent of <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Ive" class="mw-redirect" title="Jonathan Ive">Jonathan Ive</a>, and the pair worked collaboratively to rebuild Apple's status.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-95">[95]</a></sup></p><p>At the August 1997 <a href="/wiki/Macworld/iWorld" title="Macworld/iWorld">Macworld Expo</a> in Boston, Jobs announced that Apple would join Microsoft to release new versions of <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Office" title="Microsoft Office">Microsoft Office</a> for the Macintosh, and that Microsoft had made a $150 million investment in non-voting Apple stock.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> On November 10, 1997, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store_(online)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Store (online)">Apple Store</a> website, which was tied to a new build-to-order manufacturing strategy.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup></p><p>On August 15, 1998, Apple introduced a new all-in-one computer reminiscent of the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_128K" title="Macintosh 128K">Macintosh 128K</a>: the <a href="/wiki/IMac_G3" title="IMac G3">iMac</a>. The iMac design team was led by Ive, who would later design the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> and the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-levgrossman_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-levgrossman-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The iMac featured modern technology and a unique design, and sold almost 800,000 units in its first five months.<sup id="cite_ref-800kimacs_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-800kimacs-101">[101]</a></sup></p><p>During this period,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (November 2014)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> Apple completed numerous acquisitions to create a portfolio of digital production software for both professionals and consumers. In 1998, Apple purchased <a href="/wiki/Macromedia" title="Macromedia">Macromedia</a>'s Key Grip software project, signaling an expansion into the <a href="/wiki/Digital_video" title="Digital video">digital video</a> editing market. The sale was an outcome of Macromedia's decision to solely focus on web development software. The product, still unfinished at the time of the sale, was renamed "<a href="/wiki/Final_Cut_Pro" title="Final Cut Pro">Final Cut Pro</a>" when it was launched on the retail market in April 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The development of Key Grip also led to Apple's release of the consumer video-editing product <a href="/wiki/IMovie" title="IMovie">iMovie</a> in October 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell-104">[104]</a></sup> Next, Apple successfully acquired the German company Astarte, which had developed <a href="/wiki/DVD_authoring" title="DVD authoring">DVD authoring</a> technology, as well as Astarte's corresponding products and engineering team in April 2000. Astarte's digital tool DVDirector was subsequently transformed into the professional-oriented <a href="/wiki/DVD_Studio_Pro" title="DVD Studio Pro">DVD Studio Pro</a> software product. Apple then employed the same technology to create <a href="/wiki/IDVD" title="IDVD">iDVD</a> for the consumer market.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell-104">[104]</a></sup> In July 2001, Apple acquired Spruce Technologies, a PC DVD authoring platform, to incorporate their technology into Apple's expanding portfolio of digital video projects.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup></p><p><a href="/wiki/SoundJam_MP" title="SoundJam MP">SoundJam MP</a>, released by <a href="/wiki/Casady_%26_Greene" title="Casady &amp; Greene">Casady &amp; Greene</a> in 1998, was renamed "<a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a>" when Apple purchased it in 2000. The primary developers of the <a href="/wiki/MP3" title="MP3">MP3</a> player and music library software moved to Apple as part of the acquisition, and simplified SoundJam's user interface, added the ability to burn CDs, and removed its recording feature and <a href="/wiki/Skin_(computing)" title="Skin (computing)">skin</a> support.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> SoundJam was Apple's second choice for the core of Apple's music software project, originally codenamed iMusic,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> behind <a href="/wiki/Panic_Inc." title="Panic Inc.">Panic's</a> <a href="/wiki/Audion_(software)" title="Audion (software)">Audion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sasser_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sasser-110">[110]</a></sup> Apple was not able to set up a meeting with Panic in time to be fully considered as the latter was in the middle of similar negotiations with <a href="/wiki/AOL" title="AOL">AOL</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sasser_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sasser-110">[110]</a></sup></p><p>In 2002, Apple purchased <a href="/wiki/Nothing_Real" title="Nothing Real">Nothing Real</a> for their advanced digital <a href="/wiki/Compositing" title="Compositing">compositing</a> application <a href="/wiki/Shake_(software)" title="Shake (software)">Shake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Emagic" title="Emagic">Emagic</a> for the music productivity application <a href="/wiki/Logic_Pro" title="Logic Pro">Logic</a>. The purchase of Emagic made Apple the first computer manufacturer to own a music software company. The acquisition was followed by the development of Apple's consumer-level <a href="/wiki/GarageBand" title="GarageBand">GarageBand</a> application.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The release of <a href="/wiki/IPhoto" title="IPhoto">iPhoto</a> in the same year completed the <a href="/wiki/ILife" title="ILife">iLife</a> suite.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup></p><p><a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X" class="mw-redirect" title="Mac OS X">Mac OS X</a>, based on NeXT's <a href="/wiki/NeXTSTEP" title="NeXTSTEP">NeXTSTEP</a>, <a href="/wiki/OpenStep" title="OpenStep">OPENSTEP</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Berkeley_Software_Distribution" title="Berkeley Software Distribution">BSD Unix</a>, was released on March 24, 2001, after several years of development. Aimed at consumers and professionals alike, Mac OS X aimed to combine the stability, reliability, and security of <a href="/wiki/Unix" title="Unix">Unix</a> with the ease of use afforded by an overhauled user interface. To aid users in migrating from <a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_9" title="Mac OS 9">Mac OS 9</a>, the new operating system allowed the use of OS 9 applications within Mac OS X via the <a href="/wiki/Classic_Environment" class="mw-redirect" title="Classic Environment">Classic Environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup></p><p>On May 19, 2001, Apple opened its first official eponymous <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store_(retail)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Store (retail)">retail stores</a> in Virginia and California.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> On October 23 of the same year, Apple debuted the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> portable digital audio player. The product, which was first sold on November 10, 2001, was phenomenally successful with over 100 million units sold within six years.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> In 2003, Apple's <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> was introduced. The service offered online <a href="/wiki/Music_download" title="Music download">music downloads</a> for $0.99 a song and integration with the iPod. The iTunes Store quickly became the market leader in online music services, with over five billion downloads by June 19, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Two years later, the iTunes Store was the world's largest music retailer.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Intel_transition_and_financial_stability">Intel transition and financial stability</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple%27s_transition_to_Intel_processors" title="Apple's transition to Intel processors">Apple's transition to Intel processors</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MacBook_Pro.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MacBook_Pro.jpg/220px-MacBook_Pro.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="177" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="1623" data-file-height="1305"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 177px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MacBook_Pro.jpg/220px-MacBook_Pro.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="177" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MacBook_Pro.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a>, Apple's first laptop with an <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> microprocessor, introduced in 2006.</div></div></div>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/Worldwide_Developers_Conference" class="mw-redirect" title="Worldwide Developers Conference">Worldwide Developers Conference</a> keynote address on June 6, 2005, Jobs announced that Apple would begin producing <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a>-based Mac computers in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-printel_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-printel-122">[122]</a></sup> On January 10, 2006, the new <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a> and <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a> became the first Apple computers to use Intel's <a href="/wiki/Core_Duo" class="mw-redirect" title="Core Duo">Core Duo</a> CPU. By August 7, 2006, Apple made the transition to Intel chips for the entire Mac product line—over one year sooner than announced.<sup id="cite_ref-printel_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-printel-122">[122]</a></sup> The Power Mac, iBook, and PowerBook brands were retired during the transition; the <a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro" title="Mac Pro">Mac Pro</a>, <a href="/wiki/MacBook" title="MacBook">MacBook</a>, and MacBook Pro became their respective successors.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> On April 29, 2009, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Apple was building its own team of engineers to design microchips.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Apple also introduced <a href="/wiki/Boot_Camp_(software)" title="Boot Camp (software)">Boot Camp</a> in 2006 to help users install <a href="/wiki/Windows_XP" title="Windows XP">Windows XP</a> or <a href="/wiki/Windows_Vista" title="Windows Vista">Windows Vista</a> on their Intel Macs alongside Mac OS X.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup></p><p>Apple's success during this period was evident in its <a href="/wiki/Stock_price" class="mw-redirect" title="Stock price">stock price</a>. Between early 2003 and 2006, the price of Apple's stock increased more than tenfold, from around $6 per share (<a href="/wiki/Split-adjusted" class="mw-redirect" title="Split-adjusted">split-adjusted</a>) to over $80.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> When Apple surpassed <a href="/wiki/Dell" title="Dell">Dell</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Market_cap" class="mw-redirect" title="Market cap">market cap</a> in January 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-modell_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modell-128">[128]</a></sup> Jobs sent an email to Apple employees saying Dell's CEO <a href="/wiki/Michael_Dell" title="Michael Dell">Michael Dell</a> should eat his words.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> Nine years prior, Dell had said that if he ran Apple he would "shut it down and give the money back to the shareholders".<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup></p><p>Although Apple's <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">market share</a> in computers had grown, it remained far behind its competitor <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a>, accounting for about 8% of desktops and laptops in the US.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (April 2019)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p><p>Since 2001, Apple's design team has progressively abandoned the use of translucent colored plastics first used in the <a href="/wiki/IMac_G3" title="IMac G3">iMac G3</a>. This design change began with the <a href="/wiki/Titanium" title="Titanium">titanium</a>-made <a href="/wiki/PowerBook" title="PowerBook">PowerBook</a> and was followed by the <a href="/wiki/IBook" title="IBook">iBook</a>'s white <a href="/wiki/Polycarbonate" title="Polycarbonate">polycarbonate</a> structure and the flat-panel <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="2007.E2.80.932011:_Success_with_mobile_devices"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2007–2011:_Success_with_mobile_devices">2007–2011: Success with mobile devices</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg/220px-First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="2016" data-file-height="1512"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 165px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg/220px-First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="165" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:First_iPhone_Macworld_2007_DSCF1283.agr.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Newly announced iPhone on display at the 2007 <a href="/wiki/MacWorld_Expo" class="mw-redirect" title="MacWorld Expo">MacWorld Expo</a></div></div></div>
<p>During his keynote speech at the Macworld Expo on January 9, 2007, Jobs announced that Apple Computer, Inc. would thereafter be known as "Apple Inc.", because the company had shifted its emphasis from computers to consumer electronics.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> This event also saw the announcement of the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-living_Room_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-living_Room-138">[138]</a></sup> The company sold 270,000 iPhone units during the first 30 hours of sales,<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> and the device was called "a game changer for the industry".<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Apple would achieve widespread success with its iPhone, <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a>, and <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a> products, which introduced innovations in <a href="/wiki/Mobile_phone" title="Mobile phone">mobile phones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portable_music_player" class="mw-redirect" title="Portable music player">portable music players</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Personal_computer" title="Personal computer">personal computers</a> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Furthermore, by early 2007, 800,000 Final Cut Pro users were registered.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup></p><p>In an article posted on Apple's website on February 6, 2007, Jobs wrote that Apple would be willing to sell music on the iTunes Store without <a href="/wiki/Digital_rights_management" title="Digital rights management">digital rights management</a> (DRM), thereby allowing tracks to be played on third-party players, if record labels would agree to drop the technology.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> On April 2, 2007, Apple and <a href="/wiki/EMI" title="EMI">EMI</a> jointly announced the removal of DRM technology from EMI's catalog in the iTunes Store, effective in May 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> Other record
