labels eventually followed suit and Apple published a press release in January 2009 to announce that all songs on the iTunes Store are available without their <a href="/wiki/FairPlay" title="FairPlay">FairPlay</a> DRM.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup></p><p>In July 2008, Apple launched the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a> to sell third-party applications for the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> Within a month, the store sold 60 million applications and registered an average daily revenue of $1 million, with Jobs speculating in August 2008 that the App Store could become a billion-dollar business for Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> By October 2008, Apple was the third-largest mobile handset supplier in the world due to the popularity of the iPhone.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup></p><p>On December 16, 2008, Apple announced that 2009 would be the last year the corporation would attend the Macworld Expo, after more than 20 years of attendance, and that senior vice president of Worldwide Product Marketing <a href="/wiki/Phil_Schiller" title="Phil Schiller">Phil Schiller</a> would deliver the 2009 keynote address in lieu of the expected Jobs. The official press release explained that Apple was "scaling back" on trade shows in general, including <a href="/wiki/Macworld_Tokyo" class="mw-redirect" title="Macworld Tokyo">Macworld Tokyo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Expo" title="Apple Expo">Apple Expo</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, France, primarily because the enormous successes of the Apple Retail Stores and website had rendered trade shows a minor promotional channel.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup></p><p>On January 14, 2009, Jobs announced in an internal memo that he would be taking a six-month medical <a href="/wiki/Leave_of_absence" title="Leave of absence">leave of absence</a> from Apple until the end of June 2009 and would spend the time focusing on his health. In the email, Jobs stated that "the curiosity over my personal health continues to be a distraction not only for me and my family, but everyone else at Apple as well", and explained that the break would allow the company "to focus on delivering extraordinary products".<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Though Jobs was absent, Apple recorded its best non-holiday quarter (Q1 FY 2009) during the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">recession</a> with revenue of $8.16 billion and profit of $1.21 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-Inc-Apr-2009-10-Q_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-Inc-Apr-2009-10-Q-152">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup></p><p>After years of speculation and multiple rumored "leaks", Apple unveiled a large screen, tablet-like media device known as the <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a> on January 27, 2010. The iPad ran the same touch-based operating system as the iPhone, and all iPhone apps were compatible with the iPad. This gave the iPad a large app catalog on launch, though having very little development time before the release. Later that year on April 3, 2010, the iPad was launched in the US. It sold more than 300,000 units on its first day, and 500,000 by the end of the first week.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> In May of the same year, Apple's market cap exceeded that of competitor Microsoft for the first time since 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup></p><p>In June 2010, Apple released the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4" title="IPhone 4">iPhone 4</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> which introduced <a href="/wiki/Video_calling" class="mw-redirect" title="Video calling">video calling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Computer_multitasking" title="Computer multitasking">multitasking</a>, and a new <a href="/wiki/Electrical_insulation" class="mw-redirect" title="Electrical insulation">uninsulated</a> <a href="/wiki/Stainless_steel" title="Stainless steel">stainless steel</a> design that acted as the phone's antenna. Later that year, Apple again refreshed its iPod line of MP3 players by introducing a <a href="/wiki/Multi-touch" title="Multi-touch">multi-touch</a> <a href="/wiki/IPod_Nano" title="IPod Nano">iPod Nano</a>, an <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a> with <a href="/wiki/FaceTime" title="FaceTime">FaceTime</a>, and an <a href="/wiki/IPod_Shuffle" title="IPod Shuffle">iPod Shuffle</a> that brought back the <a href="/wiki/Clickwheel" title="Clickwheel">clickwheel</a> buttons of earlier generations.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> It also introduced the smaller, cheaper second generation Apple TV which allowed renting of movies and shows.<sup id="cite_ref-yahoo1_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yahoo1-161">[161]</a></sup></p><p>In October 2010, Apple shares hit an all-time high, eclipsing $300 (~$43 <a href="/wiki/Split_adjusted" class="mw-redirect" title="Split adjusted">split adjusted</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> Later that month, Apple updated the <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Air" title="MacBook Air">MacBook Air</a> laptop, <a href="/wiki/ILife" title="ILife">iLife</a> suite of applications, and unveiled <a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X_Lion" title="Mac OS X Lion">Mac OS X Lion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> the last version with the name <a href="/wiki/Mac_OS_X" class="mw-redirect" title="Mac OS X">Mac OS X</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p><p>On January 6, 2011, the company opened its <a href="/wiki/Mac_App_Store" class="mw-redirect" title="Mac App Store">Mac App Store</a>, a digital software distribution platform similar to the iOS App Store.<sup id="cite_ref-1-6-10-PCMAG-MACAPPSTORE_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1-6-10-PCMAG-MACAPPSTORE-165">[165]</a></sup></p><p>On January 17, 2011, Jobs announced in an internal Apple memo that he would take another medical leave of absence for an indefinite period to allow him to focus on his health. Chief Operating Officer <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> assumed Jobs's day-to-day operations at Apple, although Jobs would still remain "involved in major strategic decisions".<sup id="cite_ref-JobsLeave2011_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JobsLeave2011-166">[166]</a></sup> Apple became the most valuable consumer-facing brand in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> In June 2011, Jobs surprisingly took the stage and unveiled <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>, an online storage and syncing service for music, photos, files, and software which replaced <a href="/wiki/MobileMe" title="MobileMe">MobileMe</a>, Apple's previous attempt at content syncing.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> This would be the last product launch Jobs would attend before his death.
</p><p>Alongside peer entities such as <a href="/wiki/Atari" title="Atari">Atari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cisco_Systems" title="Cisco Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, Apple was featured in the documentary <i><a href="/wiki/Something_Ventured_(film)" class="mw-redirect" title="Something Ventured (film)">Something Ventured</a></i>, which premiered in 2011 and explored the three-decade era that led to the establishment and dominance of <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> It has been argued that Apple has achieved such efficiency in its supply chain that the company operates as a <a href="/wiki/Monopsony" title="Monopsony">monopsony</a> (one buyer with many sellers) and can dictate terms to its suppliers.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-supply_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-supply-172">[172]</a></sup> In July 2011, due to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_debt-ceiling_crisis_of_2011" title="United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011">American debt-ceiling crisis</a>, Apple's financial reserves were briefly larger than those of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">U.S. Government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup></p><p>On August 24, 2011, Jobs resigned his position as CEO of Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> He was replaced by Cook and Jobs became Apple's chairman. Apple did not have a chairman at the time<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> and instead had two co-lead directors, <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Jung" title="Andrea Jung">Andrea Jung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arthur_D._Levinson" title="Arthur D. Levinson">Arthur D. Levinson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> who continued with those titles until Levinson replaced Jobs as chairman of the board in November after Jobs' death.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span id="2011.E2.80.93present:_Post.E2.80.93Steve_Jobs_era.3B_Tim_Cook_leadership"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2011–present:_Post–Steve_Jobs_era;_Tim_Cook_leadership">2011–present: Post–Steve Jobs era; Tim Cook leadership</span></h3>
<p>On October 5, 2011, Steve Jobs died, marking the end of an era for Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> The first major product announcement by Apple following Jobs's passing occurred on January 19, 2012, when Apple's <a href="/wiki/Phil_Schiller" title="Phil Schiller">Phil Schiller</a> introduced iBooks Textbooks for iOS and iBook Author for Mac OS X in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Jobs had stated in his biography that he wanted to reinvent the <a href="/wiki/Textbook" title="Textbook">textbook</a> industry and education.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup></p><p>From 2011 to 2012, Apple released the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4S" title="IPhone 4S">iPhone 4S</a><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5" title="IPhone 5">iPhone 5</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> which featured improved cameras, an <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_personal_assistant" class="mw-redirect" title="Intelligent personal assistant">intelligent software assistant</a> named <a href="/wiki/Siri" title="Siri">Siri</a>, and cloud-synced data with iCloud; the <a href="/wiki/IPad_(third_generation)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPad (third generation)">third</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPad_(fourth_generation)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPad (fourth generation)">fourth</a> generation iPads, which featured <a href="/wiki/Retina_Display" class="mw-redirect" title="Retina Display">Retina displays</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lightning_strikes_again_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lightning_strikes_again-188">[188]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini" title="IPad Mini">iPad Mini</a>, which featured a 7.9-inch screen in contrast to the iPad's 9.7-inch screen.<sup id="cite_ref-mini_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mini-189">[189]</a></sup> These launches were successful, with the iPhone 5 (released September 21, 2012) becoming Apple's biggest iPhone launch with over two million pre-orders<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> and sales of three million iPads in three days following the launch of the iPad Mini and fourth generation iPad (released November 3, 2012).<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> Apple also released a third-generation 13-inch <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a> with a Retina display and new <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mac_Mini" title="Mac Mini">Mac Mini</a> computers.<sup id="cite_ref-Lightning_strikes_again_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lightning_strikes_again-188">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mini_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mini-189">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup></p><p>On August 20, 2012, Apple's rising stock price increased the company's market capitalization to a world-record $624 billion. This beat the non-inflation-adjusted record for market capitalization set by <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> On August 24, 2012, a US jury ruled that Samsung should pay Apple $1.05 billion (£665m) in damages in an <a href="/wiki/Intellectual_property" title="Intellectual property">intellectual property</a> lawsuit.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Samsung appealed the damages award, which the Court reduced by $450 million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOSS_Patents_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOSS_Patents-195">[195]</a></sup> The Court further granted Samsung's request for a new trial.<sup id="cite_ref-FOSS_Patents_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOSS_Patents-195">[195]</a></sup> On November 10, 2012, Apple confirmed a global settlement that would dismiss all lawsuits between Apple and HTC up to that date, in favor of a ten-year license agreement for current and future patents between the two companies.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> It is predicted that Apple will make $280 million a year from this deal with HTC.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup></p><p>A previously confidential email written by Jobs a year before his death was presented during the proceedings of the <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._v._Samsung_Electronics_Co." title="Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co.">Apple Inc. v. Samsung Electronics Co.</a></i> lawsuits and became publicly available in early April 2014. With a subject line that reads "Top 100 – A," the email was sent only to the company's 100 most senior employees and outlines Jobs's vision of Apple Inc.'s future under 10 subheadings. Notably, Jobs declares a "Holy War with Google" for 2011 and schedules a "new campus" for 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup></p><p>In March 2013, Apple filed a patent for an augmented reality (AR) system that can identify objects in a live video stream and present information corresponding to these objects through a computer-generated information layer overlaid on top of the real-world image.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> The company also made several high-profile hiring decisions in 2013. On July 2, 2013, Apple recruited <a href="/wiki/Paul_Deneve" title="Paul Deneve">Paul Deneve</a>, Belgian President and CEO of <a href="/wiki/Yves_Saint_Laurent_(brand)" title="Yves Saint Laurent (brand)">Yves Saint Laurent</a> as a vice president reporting directly to Tim Cook.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> A mid-October 2013 announcement revealed that <a href="/wiki/Burberry" title="Burberry">Burberry</a> CEO <a href="/wiki/Angela_Ahrendts" title="Angela Ahrendts">Angela Ahrendts</a> will commence as a senior vice president at Apple in mid-2014. Ahrendts oversaw Burberry's digital strategy for almost eight years and, during her tenure, sales increased to about $3.2 billion and shares gained more than threefold.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> She resigned from Apple in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup></p><p>Alongside Google vice-president <a href="/wiki/Vint_Cerf" title="Vint Cerf">Vint Cerf</a> and AT&amp;T CEO <a href="/wiki/Randall_Stephenson" class="mw-redirect" title="Randall Stephenson">Randall Stephenson</a>, Cook attended a closed-door summit held by <a href="/wiki/President_Obama" class="mw-redirect" title="President Obama">President Obama</a> on August 8, 2013, in regard to government surveillance and the Internet in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/Edward_Snowden" title="Edward Snowden">Edward Snowden</a> <a href="/wiki/Global_surveillance_disclosures_(2013%E2%80%93present)" title="Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)">NSA incident</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> On February 4, 2014, Cook met with <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_G%C3%BCl" title="Abdullah Gül">Abdullah Gül</a>, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President of Turkey</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> to discuss the company's involvement in the <a href="/wiki/Fatih_project" title="Fatih project">Fatih project</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup></p><p>In the first quarter of 2014, Apple reported sales of 51 million iPhones and 26 million iPads, becoming all-time quarterly sales records. It also experienced a significant year-over-year increase in Mac sales. This was contrasted with a significant drop in iPod sales.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> In May 2014, the company confirmed its intent to acquire <a href="/wiki/Dr._Dre" title="Dr. Dre">Dr. Dre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Iovine" title="Jimmy Iovine">Jimmy Iovine</a>'s audio company <a href="/wiki/Beats_Electronics" title="Beats Electronics">Beats Electronics</a>—producer of the "Beats by Dr. Dre" line of headphones and speaker products, and operator of the music streaming service <a href="/wiki/Beats_Music" title="Beats Music">Beats Music</a>—for $3 billion, and to sell their products through Apple's retail outlets and resellers. Iovine believed that Beats had always "belonged" with Apple, as the company modeled itself after Apple's "unmatched ability to marry culture and technology." The acquisition was the largest purchase in Apple's history.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup></p><p>Apple was at the top of <a href="/wiki/Interbrand" title="Interbrand">Interbrand</a>'s annual Best Global Brands report for six consecutive years; 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> and 2018 with a valuation of $214.48 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup></p><p>In January 2016, it was announced that one billion Apple devices were in active use worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup></p><p>On May 12, 2016, Apple Inc., invested $1 billion in <a href="/wiki/DiDi" title="DiDi">DiDi</a>, a Chinese <a href="/wiki/Transportation_network_company" class="mw-redirect" title="Transportation network company">transportation network company</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Information_(company)" title="The Information (company)">The Information</a></i> reported in October 2016 that Apple had taken a board seat in Didi Chuxing,<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> a move that James Vincent of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Verge" title="The Verge">The Verge</a></i> speculated could be a strategic company decision by Apple to get closer to the automobile industry,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> particularly Didi Chuxing's reported interest in self-driving cars.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup></p><p>On June 6, 2016, Fortune released Fortune 500, their list of companies ranked on revenue generation. In the trailing fiscal year (2015), Apple appeared on the list as the top tech company.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-224">[224]</a></sup> It ranked third, overall, with $233 billion in revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-224">[224]</a></sup> This represents a movement upward of two spots from the previous year's list.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Tech_Company_224-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Tech_Company-224">[224]</a></sup></p><p>On April 6, 2017, Apple launched <a href="/wiki/Clips_(software)" title="Clips (software)">Clips</a>, an app that allows iPad and iPhone users to make and edit short videos with text, graphics, and effects. The app provides a way to produce short videos to share with other users on the Messages app, <a href="/wiki/Instagram" title="Instagram">Instagram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Social_network" title="Social network">social networks</a>. Apple also introduced Live Titles for Clips that allows users to add live animated captions and titles using their voice.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup></p><p>In May 2017, Apple refreshed two of its website designs. Their <a href="/wiki/Public_relations" title="Public relations">public relations</a> "Apple Press Info" website was changed to an "Apple Newsroom" site, featuring a greater emphasis on imagery and therefore lower information density, and combines press releases, news items, and photos. Its "Apple Leadership" overview of company executives was also refreshed, adding a simpler layout with a prominent header image and two-column text fields. <i>9to5Mac</i> noted the design similarities to several of Apple's redesigned apps in <a href="/wiki/IOS_10" title="IOS 10">iOS 10</a>, particularly its <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a> and <a href="/wiki/News_(Apple)" class="mw-redirect" title="News (Apple)">News</a> software.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup></p><p>In June 2017, Apple announced the <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Smart_speaker" title="Smart speaker">smart speaker</a> aimed to compete against <a href="/wiki/Sonos" title="Sonos">Sonos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Home" title="Google Home">Google Home</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Echo" title="Amazon Echo">Amazon Echo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> Towards the end of the year, <i><a href="/wiki/TechCrunch" title="TechCrunch">TechCrunch</a></i> reported that Apple was acquiring <a href="/wiki/Shazam_(application)" title="Shazam (application)">Shazam</a>, a company specializing in music, TV, film and advertising recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> The acquisition was confirmed a few days later, reportedly costing Apple $400 million, with media reports noting that the purchase looked like a move by Apple to get data and tools to bolster its <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a> streaming service.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> The purchase was approved by EU later in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup></p><p>Also in June 2017, Apple appointed Jamie Erlicht and Zack Van Amburg to head the newly formed worldwide video unit. In November 2017, Apple announced it was branching out into original scripted programming: <a href="/wiki/Top_of_the_Morning_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Top of the Morning (TV series)">a drama series starring</a> <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Aniston" title="Jennifer Aniston">Jennifer Aniston</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reese_Witherspoon" title="Reese Witherspoon">Reese Witherspoon</a>, and a reboot of the anthology series <a href="/wiki/Amazing_Stories_(2020_TV_series)" title="Amazing Stories (2020 TV series)">Amazing Stories</a> with <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">Steven Spielberg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> In June 2018, Apple signed the <a href="/wiki/Writer%27s_Guild_of_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Writer's Guild of America">Writer's Guild of America</a>'s minimum basic agreement and <a href="/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey" title="Oprah Winfrey">Oprah Winfrey</a> to a multi-year content partnership.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> Additional partnerships for original series include <a href="/wiki/Sesame_Workshop" title="Sesame Workshop">Sesame Workshop</a> and <a href="/wiki/DHX_Media" class="mw-redirect" title="DHX Media">DHX Media</a> and its subsidiary <a href="/wiki/Peanuts_Worldwide" class="mw-redirect" title="Peanuts Worldwide">Peanuts Worldwide</a>, as well as a partnership with <a href="/wiki/A24_(company)" title="A24 (company)">A24</a> to create original films.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> As of January 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple has ordered twenty-one television series and one film. There are five series in development at Apple.
</p><p>On June 5, 2018, Apple deprecated <a href="/wiki/OpenGL" title="OpenGL">OpenGL</a> and <a href="/wiki/OpenGL_ES" title="OpenGL ES">OpenGL ES</a> across all operating systems and urged developers to use <a href="/wiki/Metal_(API)" title="Metal (API)">Metal</a> instead.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup></p><p>In August 2018, Apple purchased <a href="/wiki/Akonia_Holographics" class="mw-redirect" title="Akonia Holographics">Akonia Holographics</a> for its <a href="/wiki/Augmented_reality" title="Augmented reality">augmented reality</a> goggle lens.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> On February 14, 2019, Apple acquired DataTiger for its digital marketing technology.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup></p><p>On January 29, 2019, Apple reported its first decline in revenues and profits in a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup></p><p>In February 2019 they bought <a href="/wiki/Conversational_user_interfaces" class="mw-redirect" title="Conversational user interfaces">Conversational computing</a> company PullString (formerly ToyTalk)<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup></p><p>On July 25, 2019, Apple and <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> announced an agreement for Apple to acquire the smartphone modem business of <a href="/wiki/Intel_Mobile_Communications" title="Intel Mobile Communications">Intel Mobile Communications</a> for US$1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup></p><p>On March 30, 2020 Apple acquired Dark Sky, a local weather app for an undisclosed sum. The stand alone app be closed at the end of 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup></p><p>On April 3, 2020, Apple acquired Voysis, a Dublin Ireland based company focused on AI digital voice technology for an undisclosed sum.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup></p>
</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(2)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="Products">Products</span></h2><section class="mf-section-2 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-2">
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Apple_Inc._products" title="Timeline of Apple Inc. products">Timeline of Apple Inc. products</a></div>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Macintosh">Macintosh</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Macintosh" title="Macintosh">Macintosh</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Macintosh_models" title="Timeline of Macintosh models">Timeline of Macintosh models</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Macintosh_models_grouped_by_CPU_type" title="List of Macintosh models grouped by CPU type">List of Macintosh models grouped by CPU type</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Macintosh_models_by_case_type" title="List of Macintosh models by case type">List of Macintosh models by case type</a></div>
<p>Macintoshes currently in production:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a>: Consumer all-in-one desktop computer, introduced in 1998.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mac_Mini" title="Mac Mini">Mac Mini</a>: Consumer sub-desktop computer, introduced in 2005.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a>: Professional notebook, introduced in 2006.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro" title="Mac Pro">Mac Pro</a>: Workstation desktop computer, introduced in 2006.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/MacBook_Air" title="MacBook Air">MacBook Air</a>: Consumer ultra-thin, ultra-portable notebook, introduced in 2008.</li></ul><p>Apple sells a variety of computer accessories for Macs, including <a href="/wiki/Apple_Thunderbolt_Display" title="Apple Thunderbolt Display">Thunderbolt Display</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Mouse" title="Magic Mouse">Magic Mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Trackpad" title="Magic Trackpad">Magic Trackpad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magic_Keyboard" title="Magic Keyboard">Magic Keyboard</a>, the AirPort wireless networking products, and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Time_Capsule" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Time Capsule">Time Capsule</a>.
</p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="iPod">iPod</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IPod_line_as_of_2014.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/IPod_line_as_of_2014.png/220px-IPod_line_as_of_2014.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="189" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="703" data-file-height="604"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 189px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/IPod_line_as_of_2014.png/220px-IPod_line_as_of_2014.png" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="189" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IPod_line_as_of_2014.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>From left to right: <a href="/wiki/IPod_Shuffle" title="IPod Shuffle">iPod Shuffle</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPod_Nano" title="IPod Nano">iPod Nano</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>On October 23, 2001, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> digital music player. Several updated models have since been introduced, and the iPod brand is now the market leader in portable music players by a significant margin. More than 390 million units have shipped as of September 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> Apple has partnered with <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a> to offer the <a href="/wiki/Nike%2BiPod" class="mw-redirect" title="Nike+iPod">Nike+iPod</a> Sports Kit, enabling runners to synchronize and monitor their runs with iTunes and the Nike+ website.
</p><p>In late July 2017, Apple discontinued its <a href="/wiki/IPod_Nano" title="IPod Nano">iPod Nano</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPod_Shuffle" title="IPod Shuffle">iPod Shuffle</a> models, leaving only the <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a> available for purchase.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="iPhone">iPhone</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IPhone_montage.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/IPhone_montage.png/180px-IPhone_montage.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="490" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="828" data-file-height="2256"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 180px;height: 490px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/IPhone_montage.png/180px-IPhone_montage.png" data-alt="" data-width="180" data-height="490" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IPhone_montage.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/IPhone_(first_generation)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone (first generation)">first-generation iPhone</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_3G" title="IPhone 3G">3G</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4" title="IPhone 4">4</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5" title="IPhone 5">5</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5C" title="IPhone 5C">5C</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5S" title="IPhone 5S">5S</a> to scale.</div></div></div>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/Macworld_Conference_%26_Expo" class="mw-redirect" title="Macworld Conference &amp; Expo">Macworld Conference &amp; Expo</a> in January 2007, Steve Jobs introduced the long-anticipated<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a>, a convergence of an Internet-enabled <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphone</a> and iPod.<sup id="cite_ref-apple.com_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-apple.com-255">[255]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/IPhone_(1st_generation)" title="IPhone (1st generation)">first-generation iPhone</a> was released on June 29, 2007, for $499 (4 GB) and $599 (8 GB) with an <a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T Inc.">AT&amp;T</a> contract.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> On February 5, 2008, it was updated to have 16 GB of memory, in addition to the 8 GB and 4 GB models.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> It combined a <a href="/wiki/2.5G" class="mw-redirect" title="2.5G">2.5G</a> <a href="/wiki/Quad_band" class="mw-redirect" title="Quad band">quad band</a> <a href="/wiki/GSM" title="GSM">GSM</a> and <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_Data_Rates_for_GSM_Evolution" title="Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution">EDGE</a> cellular phone with features found in handheld devices, running a scaled-down version of <a href="/wiki/OS_X" class="mw-redirect" title="OS X">OS X</a> (dubbed <a href="/wiki/IPhone_OS" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone OS">iPhone OS</a> after the launch and later renamed to <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a>), with various Mac OS X applications such as <a href="/wiki/Safari_(web_browser)" title="Safari (web browser)">Safari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mail_(Apple)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mail (Apple)">Mail</a>. It also includes web-based and <a href="/wiki/Dashboard_(macOS)" title="Dashboard (macOS)">Dashboard</a> apps such as <a href="/wiki/Google_Maps" title="Google Maps">Google Maps</a> and Weather. The iPhone features a 3.5-inch (89 mm) touchscreen display, <a href="/wiki/Bluetooth" title="Bluetooth">Bluetooth</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a> (both "b" and "g").<sup id="cite_ref-apple.com_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-apple.com-255">[255]</a></sup></p><p>A second version, the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_3G" title="IPhone 3G">iPhone 3G</a>, was released on July 11, 2008, with a reduced price of $199 for the 8 GB model and $299 for the 16 GB model.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> This version added support for <a href="/wiki/3G" title="3G">3G</a> networking and <a href="/wiki/Assisted_GPS" title="Assisted GPS">assisted GPS</a> navigation. The flat silver back and large antenna square of the original model were eliminated in favor of a glossy, curved black or white back. Software capabilities were improved with the release of the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a>, which provided iPhone-compatible applications to download. On April 24, 2009, the App Store<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> surpassed one billion downloads.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> On June 8, 2009, Apple announced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_3GS" title="IPhone 3GS">iPhone 3GS</a>. It provided an incremental update to the device, including faster internal components, support for faster 3G speeds, video recording capability, and voice control.
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Worldwide_Developers_Conference" title="Apple Worldwide Developers Conference">Worldwide Developers Conference</a> (WWDC) on June 7, 2010, Apple announced the redesigned <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4" title="IPhone 4">iPhone 4</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> It featured a 960 × 640 display, the <a href="/wiki/Apple_A4" title="Apple A4">Apple A4</a> processor, a <a href="/wiki/Gyroscope" title="Gyroscope">gyroscope</a> for enhanced gaming, a 5MP camera with LED flash, front-facing <a href="/wiki/VGA" class="mw-redirect" title="VGA">VGA</a> camera and <a href="/wiki/FaceTime" title="FaceTime">FaceTime</a> video calling. Shortly after its release, reception issues were discovered by consumers, due to the stainless steel band around the edge of the device, which also serves as the phone's cellular signal and Wi-Fi antenna. The issue was corrected by a "Bumper Case" distributed by Apple for free to all owners for a few months. In June 2011, Apple overtook <a href="/wiki/Nokia" title="Nokia">Nokia</a> to become the world's biggest smartphone maker by volume.<sup id="cite_ref-ftover_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ftover-262">[262]</a></sup> On October 4, 2011, Apple unveiled the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4S" title="IPhone 4S">iPhone 4S</a>, which was first released on October 14, 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> It features the <a href="/wiki/Apple_A5" title="Apple A5">Apple A5</a> processor and <a href="/wiki/Siri" title="Siri">Siri</a> voice assistant technology, the latter of which Apple had acquired in 2010 from SRI International Artificial Intelligence Center.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> It also features an updated 8MP camera with new optics. Apple began a new <a href="/wiki/Accessibility" title="Accessibility">accessibility</a> feature, Made for iPhone <a href="/wiki/Hearing_aid" title="Hearing aid">Hearing Aids</a> with the iPhone 4S.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> Made for iPhone Hearing Aids feature Live Listen, it can help the user hear a conversation in a noisy room or hear someone speaking across the room.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> Apple sold 4 million iPhone 4S phones in the first three days of availability.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup></p><p>On September 12, 2012, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5" title="IPhone 5">iPhone 5</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> It has a 4-inch display, 4G LTE connectivity, and the upgraded <a href="/wiki/Apple_A6" title="Apple A6">Apple A6</a> chip, among several other improvements.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> Two million iPhones were sold in the first twenty-four hours of pre-ordering<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> and over five million handsets were sold in the first three days of its launch.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> Upon the launch of the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5S" title="IPhone 5S">iPhone 5S</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_5C" title="IPhone 5C">iPhone 5C</a>, Apple set a new record for first-weekend smartphone sales by selling over nine million devices in the first three days of its launch.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> The release of the iPhone 5S and 5C is the first time that Apple simultaneously launched two models.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup></p><p>A patent filed in July 2013 revealed the development of a new iPhone battery system that uses location data in combination with data on the user's habits to moderate the handsets' power settings accordingly. Apple is working towards a power management system that will provide features such as the ability of the iPhone to estimate the length of time a user will be away from a power source to modify energy usage and a detection function that adjusts the charging rate to best suit the type of power source that is being used.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup></p><p>In a March 2014 interview, Apple designer <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Ive" class="mw-redirect" title="Jonathan Ive">Jonathan Ive</a> used the iPhone as an example of Apple's ethos of creating high-quality, life-changing products. He explained that the phones are comparatively expensive due to the intensive effort that is used to make them:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote" style="font-size:100%"><p>We don't take so long and make the way we make for fiscal reasons ... Quite the reverse. The body is made from a single piece of machined aluminum... The whole thing is polished first to a mirror finish and then is very finely textured, except for the Apple logo. The chamfers [smoothed-off edges] are cut with diamond-tipped cutters. The cutters don't usually last very long, so we had to figure out a way of mass-manufacturing long-lasting ones. The camera cover is sapphire crystal. Look at the details around the SIM-card slot. It's extraordinary!<sup id="cite_ref-Time_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-95">[95]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>On September 9, 2014, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_6" title="IPhone 6">iPhone 6</a>, alongside the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_6_Plus" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone 6 Plus">iPhone 6 Plus</a> that both have screen sizes over 4-inches.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> One year later, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_6S" title="IPhone 6S">iPhone 6S</a>, and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_6S_Plus" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone 6S Plus">iPhone 6S Plus</a>, which introduced a new technology called 3D Touch, including an increase of the rear camera to 12 MP, and the FaceTime camera to 5 MP.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> On March 21, 2016, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_SE" title="IPhone SE">iPhone SE</a> that has a 4-inch screen size last used with the 5S and has nearly the same internal hardware as the 6S.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup></p><p>In July 2016, Apple announced that one billion iPhones had been sold.<sup id="cite_ref-1_billion_iPhones_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1_billion_iPhones-278">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup></p><p>On September 7, 2016, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_7" title="IPhone 7">iPhone 7</a> and the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_7" title="IPhone 7">iPhone 7 Plus</a>, which feature improved system and graphics performance, add water resistance, a new rear dual-camera system on the 7 Plus model, and, controversially, remove the 3.5 mm headphone jack.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg/220px-IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="5162" data-file-height="3441"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 147px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg/220px-IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="147" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IPhone_8_silver_and_iPhone_8_Plus_gold.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A gold iPhone 8 alongside a gold 8 Plus.</div></div></div>
<p>On September 12, 2017, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_8" title="IPhone 8">iPhone 8</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_8" title="IPhone 8">iPhone 8 Plus</a>, standing as evolutionary updates to its previous phones with a faster processor, improved display technology, upgraded camera systems and wireless charging.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> The company also announced <a href="/wiki/IPhone_X" title="IPhone X">iPhone X</a>, which radically changes the hardware of the iPhone lineup, removing the home button in favor of <a href="/wiki/Face_ID" title="Face ID">facial recognition technology</a> and featuring a near <a href="/wiki/Bezel_(screen)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bezel (screen)">bezel</a>-less design along with <a href="/wiki/Wireless_charging" class="mw-redirect" title="Wireless charging">wireless charging</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup></p><p>On September 12, 2018, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_XS" title="IPhone XS">iPhone XS</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_XS_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone XS Max">iPhone XS Max</a> and <a href="/wiki/IPhone_XR" title="IPhone XR">iPhone XR</a>. The iPhone XS and iPhone XS Max features Super Retina displays, a faster and improved dual camera system that offers breakthrough photo and video features, the first 7-nanometer chip in a smartphone — the A12 Bionic chip with next-generation Neural Engine — faster Face ID, wider stereo sound and introduces Dual SIM to iPhone. The iPhone XR comes in an all-screen glass and aluminium design with the most advanced LCD in a smartphone featuring a 6.1-inch Liquid Retina display, A12 Bionic chip with next-generation Neural Engine, the TrueDepth camera system, Face ID and an advanced camera system that creates dramatic portraits using a single camera lens.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup></p><p>On September 10, 2019, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_11" title="IPhone 11">iPhone 11</a>, <a href="/wiki/IPhone_11_Pro" title="IPhone 11 Pro">iPhone 11 Pro</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_11_Pro_Max" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone 11 Pro Max">iPhone 11 Pro Max</a>. The iPhone 11 features the same Liquid Retina LCD display used in 2018's <a href="/wiki/IPhone_XR" title="IPhone XR">iPhone XR</a>. Overall, the iPhone 11 retains the same glass and aluminum design as the iPhone XR while adding in new features such as the addition of an Ultra-Wide 12mp camera, a battery that lasts 1 hour longer than the iPhone XR and an <a href="/wiki/IP_Code" title="IP Code">IP68</a> rating for water and dust resistance. The iPhone 11 Pro and iPhone 11 Pro Max feature an all-new textured matte glass and stainless steel design and a triple camera setup that included an Ultra Wide, Wide and Telephoto camera. The iPhone 11 Pro series' battery life is capable of lasting up to 5 hours more than the iPhone XS and XS Max. The iPhone 11 Pro and Pro Max also features a new Super Retina XDR OLED display that is capable of a screen brightness of 800 nits. All new iPhones announced at Apple's September 2019 feature an <a href="/wiki/Apple_A13" title="Apple A13">A13 Bionic</a> chip with a third-generation Neural Engine, an Apple U1 chip, spatial audio playback, a low light photo mode and an improved Face ID system.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup></p><p>On April 15, 2020, Apple announced a new <a href="/wiki/IPhone_SE_(2020)" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhone SE (2020)">iPhone SE</a>. It replicates the iPhone 8 design - has a 4.7-inch screen, sizable bezels on the top and bottom, and a home button with Touch ID. Yet, the 2020 iPhone SE features A13 Bionic chip and a 12 MP rear wide camera, similarly to the iPhone 11 lineup.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="iPad">iPad</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a></div>
<p>On January 27, 2010, Apple introduced their much-anticipated media <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">tablet</a>, the <a href="/wiki/IPad" title="IPad">iPad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup> It offers multi-touch interaction with multimedia formats including newspapers, e-books, photos, videos, music, word processing documents, video games, and most existing iPhone apps using a 9.7-inch screen.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> It also includes a mobile version of <a href="/wiki/Safari_(web_browser)" title="Safari (web browser)">Safari</a> for web browsing, as well as access to the App Store, <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a> Library, <a href="/wiki/IBookstore" class="mw-redirect" title="IBookstore">iBookstore</a>, Contacts, and Notes. Content is downloadable via <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a> and optional <a href="/wiki/3G" title="3G">3G</a> service or synced through the user's computer.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors-iPad-event_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors-iPad-event-293">[293]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T Inc.">AT&amp;T</a> was initially the sole U.S. provider of 3G wireless access for the iPad.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IPad_Air_2.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/IPad_Air_2.png/180px-IPad_Air_2.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="266" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="1734" data-file-height="2566"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 180px;height: 266px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/IPad_Air_2.png/180px-IPad_Air_2.png" data-alt="" data-width="180" data-height="266" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IPad_Air_2.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/IPad_Air_2" title="IPad Air 2">iPad Air 2</a> in gold</div></div></div>
<p>On March 2, 2011, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPad_2" title="IPad 2">iPad 2</a>, which had a faster processor and a camera on the front and back. It also added support for optional 3G service provided by <a href="/wiki/Verizon_Wireless" title="Verizon Wireless">Verizon</a> in addition to <a href="/wiki/AT%26T_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="AT&amp;T Inc.">AT&amp;T</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes-ipad2_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-ipad2-295">[295]</a></sup> The availability of the iPad 2 was initially limited as a result of a devastating <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami">earthquake and tsunami</a> in Japan in March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup></p><p>The third-generation iPad was released on March 7, 2012, and marketed as "<a href="/wiki/IPad_(3rd_generation)" title="IPad (3rd generation)">the new iPad</a>". It added <a href="/wiki/LTE_(telecommunication)" title="LTE (telecommunication)">LTE</a> service from AT&amp;T or Verizon, an upgraded <a href="/wiki/Apple_A5X" title="Apple A5X">A5X</a> processor, and Retina display. The dimensions and form factor remained relatively unchanged, with the new iPad being a fraction thicker and heavier than the previous version and featuring minor positioning changes.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg/220px-A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 165px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg/220px-A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="165" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:A_silver_iPad_Pro_with_black_screen_bezzles.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The iPad Pro 2nd generation</div></div></div>
<p>On October 23, 2012, Apple's fourth-generation iPad came out, marketed as the "<a href="/wiki/IPad_(4th_generation)" title="IPad (4th generation)">iPad with Retina display</a>". It added the upgraded <a href="/wiki/Apple_A6X" title="Apple A6X">A6X</a> processor and replaced the traditional 30-pin dock connector with the all-digital <a href="/wiki/Lightning_(connector)" title="Lightning (connector)">Lightning connector</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini" title="IPad Mini">iPad Mini</a> was also introduced. It featured a reduced 7.9-inch display and much of the same internal specifications as the iPad 2.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup></p><p>On October 22, 2013, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/IPad_Air" title="IPad Air">iPad Air</a> and the iPad Mini with Retina Display, both featuring a new 64-bit Apple A7 processor.<sup id="cite_ref-iPad_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iPad-300">[300]</a></sup></p><p>The <a href="/wiki/IPad_Air_2" title="IPad Air 2">iPad Air 2</a> was unveiled on October 16, 2014. It added better graphics and central processing and a camera burst mode as well as minor updates. The <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini_3" title="IPad Mini 3">iPad Mini 3</a> was unveiled at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-iPad_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iPad-300">[300]</a></sup></p><p>Since its launch, iPad users have downloaded over three billion apps. The total number of App Store downloads, as of June 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, is over 100 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup></p><p>On September 9, 2015, Apple announced the <a href="/wiki/IPad_Pro" title="IPad Pro">iPad Pro</a>, an iPad with a 12.9-inch display that supports two new accessories, the <a href="/wiki/Smart_Keyboard" class="mw-redirect" title="Smart Keyboard">Smart Keyboard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Pencil" title="Apple Pencil">Apple Pencil</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> An updated <a href="/wiki/IPad_Mini_4" title="IPad Mini 4">IPad Mini 4</a> was announced at the same time.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> A 9.7-inch iPad Pro was announced on March 21, 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> On June 5, 2017, Apple announced a new iPad Pro with a 10.5-inch display to replace the 9.7 inch model and an updated 12.9-inch model.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Apple_Watch">Apple Watch</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Watch-.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Apple_Watch-.jpg/220px-Apple_Watch-.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="4700" data-file-height="3133"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 147px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Apple_Watch-.jpg/220px-Apple_Watch-.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="147" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Watch-.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Apple Watch quickly became the best-selling wearable device, with the shipment of 11.4 million smart watches in the first half of 2015, according to analyst firm Canalys.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The original Apple Watch <a href="/wiki/Smartwatch" title="Smartwatch">smartwatch</a> was announced by Tim Cook on September 9, 2014, being introduced as a product with health and fitness-tracking.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> It was released on April 24, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup></p><p>The second generation of Apple Watch, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch_Series_2" title="Apple Watch Series 2">Apple Watch Series 2</a>, was released in September 2016, featuring greater water resistance, a faster processor, and brighter display. It was also released alongside a cheaper Series 1.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup></p><p>On September 12, 2017, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch_Series_3" title="Apple Watch Series 3">Apple Watch Series 3</a> featuring LTE cellular connectivity, giving the wearable independence from an iPhone<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> except for the setup process.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup></p><p>On September 12, 2018, Apple introduced the <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch_Series_4" title="Apple Watch Series 4">Apple Watch Series 4</a>, featuring new display, <a href="/wiki/Electrocardiogram" class="mw-redirect" title="Electrocardiogram">electrocardiogram</a>, and fall detection.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup></p><p>On September 10, 2019, Apple introduced the Apple Watch Series 5, featuring a new magnetometer, a faster processor, and a new always-on display. The Series 4 was discontinued.
</p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Apple_TV">Apple TV</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a></div>
<p>At the 2007 Macworld conference, Jobs demonstrated the <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">Apple TV</a> (Jobs accidentally referred to the device as "iTV", its codename, while on stage), a set-top video device intended to bridge the sale of content from iTunes with high-definition televisions.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> The device, running a variant of Mac OS X, links up to a user's TV and syncs over the wireless or wired network with one computer's iTunes library and can stream content from an additional four. The Apple TV originally incorporated a 40 GB hard drive for storage, included outputs for <a href="/wiki/HDMI" title="HDMI">HDMI</a> and <a href="/wiki/Component_video" title="Component video">component video</a>, and played video at a maximum resolution of <a href="/wiki/720p" title="720p">720p</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-living_Room_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-living_Room-138">[138]</a></sup> On May 30, 2007, a 160 GB hard disk drive was released alongside the existing 40 GB model.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup> A software update released on January 15, 2008, allowed media to be purchased directly from the Apple TV.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup></p><p>In September 2009, Apple discontinued the original 40 GB Apple TV but continued to produce and sell the 160 GB Apple TV. On September 1, 2010, Apple released a completely redesigned Apple TV running on an iOS variant and discontinued the older model, which ran on a Mac OS X variant. The new device is one-fourth the size, runs quieter, and replaces the need for a hard drive with media streaming from any iTunes library on the network along with 8 GB of <a href="/wiki/Flash_memory" title="Flash memory">flash memory</a> to <a href="/wiki/Cache_(computing)" title="Cache (computing)">cache</a> downloaded media. Like the iPad and the iPhone, Apple TV runs on an A4 processor. The memory included in the device is half of that in the <a href="/wiki/IPhone_4" title="IPhone 4">iPhone 4</a> at 256 MB; the same as the iPad, iPhone 3GS, third and fourth-generation <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">iPod Touch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup></p><p>It has HDMI out as the only video output source. Features include access to the iTunes Store to rent movies and TV shows (purchasing has been discontinued), streaming from internet video sources, including <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> and <a href="/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a>, and media streaming from an iTunes library. Apple also reduced the price of the device to $99. A third generation of the device was introduced at an Apple event on March 7, 2012, with new features such as higher resolution (1080p) and a new user interface.
</p><p>At the September 9, 2015, event, Apple unveiled an overhauled Apple TV, which now runs a subsequent variant of iOS called <a href="/wiki/TvOS" title="TvOS">tvOS</a>, and contains 32 GB or 64 GB of NAND Flash to store games, programs, and to cache the current media playing. The release also coincided with the opening of a separate Apple TV App Store and a new <a href="/wiki/Siri_Remote" title="Siri Remote">Siri Remote</a> with a glass <a href="/wiki/Touchpad" title="Touchpad">touchpad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gyroscope" title="Gyroscope">gyroscope</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Microphone" title="Microphone">microphone</a>.
</p><p>On December 12, 2016, Apple released a new iOS and tvOS <a href="/wiki/Media_player_(software)" class="mw-redirect" title="Media player (software)">media player</a> app called <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV_(software)" title="Apple TV (software)">TV</a> to replace the existing "Videos" iOS application.
</p><p>At the September 12, 2017, event, Apple released a new <a href="/wiki/4K_resolution" title="4K resolution">4K</a> Apple TV with the same form factor as the 4th Generation model. The 4K model is powered by the <a href="/wiki/Apple_A10X" title="Apple A10X">A10X</a> SoC designed in-house that also powers their second-generation iPad Pro. The 4K model also has support for <a href="/wiki/High_dynamic_range" title="High dynamic range">high dynamic range</a>.
</p><p>On March 25, 2019, Apple announced <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV%2B" title="Apple TV+">Apple TV+</a>, their upcoming <a href="/wiki/Over-the-top_media_services" class="mw-redirect" title="Over-the-top media services">over-the-top</a> subscription <a href="/wiki/Video_on-demand" class="mw-redirect" title="Video on-demand">video on-demand</a> <a href="/wiki/Web_television" title="Web television">web television</a> service, will arrive Fall 2019. TV+ features exclusive <a href="/wiki/List_of_original_programs_distributed_by_Apple" class="mw-redirect" title="List of original programs distributed by Apple">original shows, movies, and documentaries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> They also announced an update to the TV app with a new "<a href="/wiki/Apple_TV_Channels" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple TV Channels">Channels</a>" feature and that the TV app will expand to <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a>, numerous <a href="/wiki/Smart_television" class="mw-redirect" title="Smart television">smart television</a> models, <a href="/wiki/Roku" title="Roku">Roku</a> devices, and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Fire_TV" title="Amazon Fire TV">Amazon Fire TV</a> devices later in 2019.
</p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="HomePod">HomePod</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png/220px-An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="739" data-file-height="533"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 159px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png/220px-An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="159" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:An_Apple_HomePod_speaker_.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A white <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a> on display</div></div></div>
<p>Apple's first smart speaker, the <a href="/wiki/HomePod" title="HomePod">HomePod</a> was released on February 9, 2018, after being delayed from its initial December 2017 release. It also features seven <a href="/wiki/Tweeters" class="mw-redirect" title="Tweeters">tweeters</a> in the base, a four-inch <a href="/wiki/Woofer" title="Woofer">woofer</a> in the top, and six microphones for voice control and acoustic optimization<sup id="cite_ref-:0_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-321">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wired-review_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wired-review-323">[323]</a></sup> On September 12, 2018, Apple announced that HomePod is adding new features—search by lyrics, set multiple timers, make and receive phone calls, Find My iPhone, Siri Shortcuts—and Siri languages.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup> In 2019, Apple, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/ZigBee" class="mw-redirect" title="ZigBee">Zigbee Alliance</a> announced a partnership to make smart home products work together.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Software">Software</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a>, <a href="/wiki/WatchOS" title="WatchOS">watchOS</a>, and <a href="/wiki/TvOS" title="TvOS">tvOS</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg/220px-WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="2575" data-file-height="1717"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 147px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg/220px-WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="147" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WWDC_2011_Moscone_West_Exterior.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Apple_Worldwide_Developers_Conference" title="Apple Worldwide Developers Conference">Apple Worldwide Developers Conference</a> is held annually by Apple to showcase its new software and technologies for software developers.</div></div></div>
<p>Apple develops its own <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">operating systems</a> to run on its devices, including <a href="/wiki/MacOS" title="MacOS">macOS</a> for Mac personal computers,<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/IOS" title="IOS">iOS</a> for its iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch smartphones and tablets,<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/WatchOS" title="WatchOS">watchOS</a> for its Apple Watch smartwatches,<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/TvOS" title="TvOS">tvOS</a> for its Apple TV digital media player.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup></p><p>For iOS and macOS, Apple also develops its own software titles, including <a href="/wiki/Pages_(word_processor)" title="Pages (word processor)">Pages</a> for writing, <a href="/wiki/Numbers_(spreadsheet)" title="Numbers (spreadsheet)">Numbers</a> for spreadsheets, and <a href="/wiki/Keynote_(presentation_software)" title="Keynote (presentation software)">Keynote</a> for presentations, as part of its <a href="/wiki/IWork" title="IWork">iWork</a> productivity suite.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> For macOS, it also offers <a href="/wiki/IMovie" title="IMovie">iMovie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Final_Cut_Pro_X" title="Final Cut Pro X">Final Cut Pro X</a> for video editing,<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/GarageBand" title="GarageBand">GarageBand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Logic_Pro_X" class="mw-redirect" title="Logic Pro X">Logic Pro X</a> for music creation.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup></p><p>Apple's range of server software includes the operating system <a href="/wiki/MacOS_Server" title="MacOS Server">macOS Server</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_macOS_Server_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_macOS_Server-333">[333]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Apple_Remote_Desktop" title="Apple Remote Desktop">Apple Remote Desktop</a>, a remote systems management application;<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Xsan" title="Xsan">Xsan</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Storage_area_network" title="Storage area network">storage area network</a> file system.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_macOS_Server_333-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_macOS_Server-333">[333]</a></sup></p><p>Apple also offers online services with <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a>, which provides <a href="/wiki/File_hosting_service" title="File hosting service">cloud storage</a> and synchronization for a wide range of user data, including documents, photos, music, device backups, and application data,<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a>, its music and video <a href="/wiki/Streaming_media" title="Streaming media">streaming service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Electric_vehicles">Electric vehicles</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_electric_car_project" title="Apple electric car project">Apple electric car project</a></div>
<p>According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Sydney_Morning_Herald" class="mw-redirect" title="Sydney Morning Herald">Sydney Morning Herald</a></i>, Apple wants to start producing an <a href="/wiki/Electric_car" title="Electric car">electric car</a> with <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_driving" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous driving">autonomous driving</a> as soon as 2020. Apple has made efforts to recruit battery development engineers and other electric automobile engineers from <a href="/wiki/A123_Systems" title="A123 Systems">A123 Systems</a>, <a href="/wiki/LG_Chem" title="LG Chem">LG Chem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samsung_Electronics" title="Samsung Electronics">Samsung Electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panasonic" title="Panasonic">Panasonic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toshiba" title="Toshiba">Toshiba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johnson_Controls" title="Johnson Controls">Johnson Controls</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Motors" class="mw-redirect" title="Tesla Motors">Tesla Motors</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup></p>
</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(3)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_identity">Corporate identity</span></h2><section class="mf-section-3 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-3">
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Logo">Logo</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r923042769/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner"
