style="width:104px;max-width:104px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_first_logo.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_first_logo.png/100px-Apple_first_logo.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="145" data-file-width="412" data-file-height="599"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 100px;height: 145px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_first_logo.png/100px-Apple_first_logo.png" data-alt="" data-width="100" data-height="145"> </span></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">First Apple logo<br>(1976–77)<sup id="cite_ref-logo_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo-338">[338]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/100px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="110" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="563"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 100px;height: 110px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/100px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png" data-alt="" data-width="100" data-height="110" data-srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/150px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/200px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png 2x"> </span></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">First official logo<br>(1977–98)<sup id="cite_ref-logo_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo-338">[338]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_Logo_1998.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/43/Apple_Logo_1998.jpg/100px-Apple_Logo_1998.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="117" data-file-width="240" data-file-height="280"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 100px;height: 117px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/43/Apple_Logo_1998.jpg/100px-Apple_Logo_1998.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="100" data-height="117"> </span></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Second official logo<br>(1998–03)<sup id="cite_ref-logo_338-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo-338">[338]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_logo_black.svg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/100px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="119" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1187"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 100px;height: 119px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/100px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png" data-alt="" data-width="100" data-height="119" data-srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/150px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_logo_black.svg/200px-Apple_logo_black.svg.png 2x"> </span></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Current logo<br>(since 2003)<sup id="cite_ref-logo_338-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-logo-338">[338]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Typography_of_Apple_Inc." title="Typography of Apple Inc.">Typography of Apple Inc.</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Apple logo" redirects here. For the programming language, see <a href="/wiki/Apple_Logo" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Logo">Apple Logo</a>.</div>
<p>According to Steve Jobs, the company's name was inspired by his visit to an apple farm while on a <a href="/wiki/Fruitarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Fruitarian">fruitarian</a> diet. Jobs thought the name "Apple" was "fun, spirited and not intimidating".<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup></p><p>Apple's first logo, designed by <a href="/wiki/Ron_Wayne" class="mw-redirect" title="Ron Wayne">Ron Wayne</a>, depicts <a href="/wiki/Sir_Isaac_Newton" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Isaac Newton">Sir Isaac Newton</a> sitting under an apple tree. It was almost immediately replaced by <a href="/wiki/Rob_Janoff" title="Rob Janoff">Rob Janoff</a>'s "rainbow Apple", the now-familiar rainbow-colored silhouette of an apple with a bite taken out of it. Janoff presented Jobs with several different monochromatic themes for the "bitten" logo, and Jobs immediately took a liking to it. However, Jobs insisted that the logo be colorized to humanize the company.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> The logo was designed with a bite so that it would not be confused with a cherry.<sup id="cite_ref-creativebits_interview_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-creativebits_interview-342">[342]</a></sup> The colored stripes were conceived to make the logo more accessible, and to represent the fact the Apple II could generate graphics in color.<sup id="cite_ref-creativebits_interview_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-creativebits_interview-342">[342]</a></sup> This logo is often erroneously referred to as a tribute to <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a>, with the bite mark a reference to <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing#Death" title="Alan Turing">his method of suicide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> Both Janoff and Apple deny any homage to Turing in the design of the logo.<sup id="cite_ref-creativebits_interview_342-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-creativebits_interview-342">[342]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup></p><p>On August 27, 1999<sup id="cite_ref-web.archive.org_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-web.archive.org-346">[346]</a></sup> (the year following the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/IMac_G3" title="IMac G3">iMac G3</a>), Apple officially dropped the rainbow scheme and began to use monochromatic logos nearly identical in shape to the previous rainbow incarnation. An <a href="/wiki/Aqua_(user_interface)" title="Aqua (user interface)">Aqua</a>-themed version of the monochrome logo was used from 1998 to 2003, and a glass-themed version was used from 2007 to 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup></p><p>Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">Beatles</a> fans,<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup> but Apple Inc. had name and logo trademark issues with <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps Ltd.</a>, a multimedia company started by the Beatles in 1968. This resulted in a <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps_v_Apple_Computer" title="Apple Corps v Apple Computer">series of lawsuits</a> and tension between the two companies. These issues ended with the settling of their lawsuit in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Advertising">Advertising</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._advertising" title="Apple Inc. advertising">Apple Inc. advertising</a></div>
<p>Apple's first slogan, "<a href="/wiki/Byte" title="Byte">Byte</a> into an Apple", was coined in the late 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> From 1997 to 2002, the slogan "<a href="/wiki/Think_Different" class="mw-redirect" title="Think Different">Think Different</a>" was used in advertising campaigns, and is still closely associated with Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> Apple also has slogans for specific product lines — for example, "iThink, therefore iMac" was used in 1998 to promote the iMac,<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> and "Say hello to iPhone" has been used in iPhone advertisements.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> "Hello" was also used to introduce the original Macintosh, <a href="/wiki/Newton_(platform)" class="mw-redirect" title="Newton (platform)">Newton</a>, iMac ("hello (again)"), and iPod.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup></p><p>From the introduction of the Macintosh in 1984, with the <a href="/wiki/1984_(television_commercial)" class="mw-redirect" title="1984 (television commercial)">1984 Super Bowl advertisement</a> to the more modern <a href="/wiki/Get_a_Mac" title="Get a Mac">Get a Mac</a> adverts, Apple has been recognized for its efforts towards effective advertising and marketing for its products. However, claims made by later campaigns <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._advertising#Criticism" title="Apple Inc. advertising">were criticized</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> particularly the 2005 Power Mac ads.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> Apple's product advertisements gained a lot of attention as a result of their eye-popping graphics and catchy tunes.<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_News_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_News-358">[358]</a></sup> Musicians who benefited from an improved profile as a result of their songs being included on Apple advertisements include Canadian singer <a href="/wiki/Feist_(singer)" title="Feist (singer)">Feist</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/1234_(Feist_song)" title="1234 (Feist song)">1234</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Yael_Naim" title="Yael Naim">Yael Naïm</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/New_Soul" title="New Soul">New Soul</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_News_358-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_News-358">[358]</a></sup></p><p>Apple owns a <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> channel where they release advertisements, tips, and introductions for their devices.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Brand_Semiotics">Brand Semiotics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Semiotics" title="Semiotics">Semiotics</a> is the study of how meaning is derived from <a href="/wiki/Symbols" class="mw-redirect" title="Symbols">symbols</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sign" title="Sign">signs</a> and provides major insight for understanding <a href="/wiki/Brand_management" title="Brand management">brand management</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brand_loyalty" title="Brand loyalty">brand loyalty</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_de_Saussure" title="Ferdinand de Saussure">Ferdinand de Saussure</a>, a Swiss linguist and <a href="/wiki/Semiotician" class="mw-redirect" title="Semiotician">semiotician</a>, created a semiotic model that identifies two parts of a sign: the <a href="/wiki/Signified_and_signifier" title="Signified and signifier">signified and signifier</a>. The signifier is the perceptual component that we physically see, and the signified is then the concept which the sign refers to. In Saussure’s model, the sign results from the recognition of a sound or object with a concept. In his model, the signified and signifier are “as inseparable as two sides of a piece of paper".<sup id="cite_ref-Chandler_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-361">[361]</a></sup> The second popular semiotic model that exists is the Peircean Model. <a href="/wiki/Charles_Sanders_Pierce" class="mw-redirect" title="Charles Sanders Pierce">Charles Sanders Pierce</a> was a logician. His model, like Saussure’s model, involved the relationship between the elements of signs and objects. However, the Peircean model added that whoever is decoding the sign must have some previous understanding or knowledge about the transmitted message.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup> Peirce’s model can be represented using the three sides of triangle: the <a href="/wiki/Representamen" class="mw-redirect" title="Representamen">representamen</a> (the sign), an object (what the sign represents), and the <a href="/wiki/Interpretant" title="Interpretant">interpretant</a> (the produced effect by the sign).<sup id="cite_ref-Chandler_361-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chandler-361">[361]</a></sup></p><p>The symbolic representation that a <a href="/wiki/Brand" title="Brand">brand</a> carries can affect how a <a href="/wiki/Consumer" title="Consumer">consumer</a> “recalls, internalizes, and relates” to the performance of a company. There is plenty of evidence to show that a company can easily fail if they do not keep track of how the brand changes with the <a href="/wiki/Media_culture" title="Media culture">media culture</a>. Semiotic research can be used to help a company relate to their customer’s culture over time and help their brand to stand out in competitive markets.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup></p><p>The first two Apple logos are drastically different from each other. However, they both share the sign of an apple. In the original logo designed by <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Wayne" title="Ronald Wayne">Ronald Wayne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sir_Isaac_Newton" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Isaac Newton">Sir Isaac Newton</a> is seen sitting under the infamous apple tree about to bear fruit above, just before his discovery of gravity. When one analyzes the <a href="/wiki/Semiotics" title="Semiotics">semiotics</a> with Saussure’s model, the signified, or sign, is the apple. The signifier represents discovery, innovation, and the notion of thought.<sup id="cite_ref-SlideShare_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlideShare-364">[364]</a></sup></p><p>It was quickly realized that the original logo was too complicated and intellectual for the needed purpose. The company’s mission was, and still is, to simplify technology for the everyday life. A fun and clever logo that spoke to computer-savvy people was needed. In 1977, <a href="/wiki/Rob_Janoff" title="Rob Janoff">Rob Janoff</a> created the iconic rainbow apple symbol that is still recognized today. The logo had double meaning and differed from the many serious logos in existence at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup></p><p>Apple Inc. is well known for being an innovative company who challenge the status quo and established standards. Again, using Saussure’s semiotic model, the signified, is an apple, but with a bite taken out of it. Because Apple is seen as a “challenger” in the industry, the most common signifier is the forbidden fruit from the Biblical reference, the Garden of Eden.<sup id="cite_ref-Cowin_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cowin-366">[366]</a></sup> The signified is the bite from the apple, and the represented signifier is the tree of knowledge. Thus, symbolizing Apple as a “rebellious young company” ready to challenge the world.<sup id="cite_ref-SlideShare_364-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlideShare-364">[364]</a></sup> An even further semiotic analysis is that Adam and Eve gained a great deal of knowledge after the apple was bitten. So, the bitten apple is a sign for the “promise of knowledge” that an Apple user may gain from the product.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Semiotics" title="Semiotics">semiotics</a> of the bite and the color of the logo can also be looked at from a technologic viewpoint. The bite is the <a href="/wiki/Signified" class="mw-redirect" title="Signified">signified</a> and the computer storage unit, <a href="/wiki/Byte" title="Byte">byte</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/Signifier" class="mw-redirect" title="Signifier">signifier</a>. The rainbow color of the logo portrays the message that the its <a href="/wiki/Computer_monitor" title="Computer monitor">computer monitor</a> could be produce color images.<sup id="cite_ref-SlideShare_364-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlideShare-364">[364]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a> also argued that color was crucial for “humanizing the company” at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-Cowin_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cowin-366">[366]</a></sup></p><p>The only thing to change with the logo since 1977 has been the color. In 1998, a <a href="/wiki/Monochromatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Monochromatic">monochromatic</a> logo was implemented with the release of the first <a href="/wiki/IMac" title="IMac">iMac</a>. This was the first Mac to not have the iconic rainbow-colored apple since its creation 20 years prior.<sup id="cite_ref-Biricik_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biricik-367">[367]</a></sup> The new look was the future or new era of Apple Inc. The color of the logo may have changed; however, the Apple logo has become an iconic signifier for innovation and knowledge to an entire culture of Apple users.<sup id="cite_ref-Cowin_366-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cowin-366">[366]</a></sup> The logo’s shape had become untouchable and Apple’s message was as clear as ever, it’s better to be different.<sup id="cite_ref-Biricik_367-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biricik-367">[367]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Brand_loyalty">Brand loyalty</span></h3>
<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:30%; ;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r887775652">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{margin:0.5em auto 0.8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft p,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright p{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:larger;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:360px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{min-width:100%;margin:0 0 0.8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">"The scenes I witnessed at the opening of the new Apple store in London's <a href="/wiki/Covent_Garden" title="Covent Garden">Covent Garden</a> were more like an evangelical prayer meeting than a chance to buy a phone or a laptop."</div>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">—<a href="/wiki/Alex_Riley_(comedian)" title="Alex Riley (comedian)">Alex Riley</a>, writing for the BBC<sup id="cite_ref-riley1_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riley1-368">[368]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Apple customers gained a reputation for devotion and loyalty early in the company's history. In 1984, <i><a href="/wiki/BYTE" class="mw-redirect" title="BYTE">BYTE</a></i> stated that:<sup id="cite_ref-lemmons198412_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lemmons198412-369">[369]</a></sup></p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"><blockquote class="templatequote" style="font-size:100%"><p>There are two kinds of people in the world: people who say Apple isn't just a company, it's a cause; and people who say Apple isn't a cause, it's just a company. Both groups are right. Nature has suspended the principle of noncontradiction where Apple is concerned.
Apple is more than just a company because its founding has some of the qualities of myth ... Apple is two guys in a garage undertaking the mission of bringing computing power, once reserved for big corporations, to ordinary individuals with ordinary budgets. The company's growth from two guys to a billion-dollar corporation exemplifies the <a href="/wiki/American_Dream" title="American Dream">American Dream</a>. Even as a large corporation, Apple plays David to IBM's Goliath, and thus has the sympathetic role in that myth.</p></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg/220px-Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="576"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 165px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg/220px-Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="165" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ifc_shanghai_Apple_Store.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Apple aficionados wait in line around an Apple Store in Shanghai in anticipation of a new product.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Apple_evangelist" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple evangelist">Apple evangelists</a> were actively engaged by the company at one time, but this was after the phenomenon had already been firmly established. Apple <a href="/wiki/Evangelism_marketing" title="Evangelism marketing">evangelist</a> <a href="/wiki/Guy_Kawasaki" title="Guy Kawasaki">Guy Kawasaki</a> has called the brand fanaticism "something that was stumbled upon,"<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> while Ive explained in 2014 that "People have an incredibly personal relationship" with Apple's products.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_95-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-95">[95]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a> openings and new product releases can draw crowds of hundreds, with some waiting in line as much as a day before the opening.<sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_1_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_1-371">[371]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_2_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_2-372">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_3_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_3-373">[373]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_4_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_4-374">[374]</a></sup> The opening of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a> "Cube" store in 2006 became the setting of a marriage proposal, and had visitors from Europe who flew in for the event.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> In June 2017, a newlywed couple took their wedding photos inside the then-recently opened Orchard Road Apple Store in Singapore.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> The high level of brand loyalty has been criticized and ridiculed, applying the epithet "Apple fanboy" and mocking the lengthy lines before a product launch.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> An internal memo leaked in 2015 suggested the company planned to discourage long lines and direct customers to purchase its products on its website.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup></p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a></i> magazine named Apple the most admired company in the United States in 2008, and in the world from 2008 to 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup> On September 30, 2013, Apple surpassed <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> to become the world's most valuable brand in the <a href="/wiki/Omnicom_Group" title="Omnicom Group">Omnicom Group</a>'s "Best Global Brands" report.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group" title="Boston Consulting Group">Boston Consulting Group</a> has ranked Apple as the world's most innovative brand every year since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup></p><p><i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> in 1985 stated that "Apple above all else is a marketing company".<sup id="cite_ref-esd19850319_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-esd19850319-387">[387]</a></sup> John Sculley agreed, telling <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> newspaper in 1997 that "People talk about technology, but Apple was a marketing company. It was the marketing company of the decade."<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup> Research in 2002 by <a href="/wiki/Nielsen_Online" class="mw-redirect" title="Nielsen Online">NetRatings</a> indicate that the average Apple consumer was usually more affluent and better educated than other PC company consumers. The research indicated that this correlation could stem from the fact that on average Apple Inc. products were more expensive than other PC products.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup></p><p>
In response to a query about the devotion of loyal Apple consumers, Jonathan Ive responded:<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"></p><blockquote class="templatequote" style="font-size:100%"><p>What people are responding to is much bigger than the object. They are responding to something rare—a group of people who do more than simply make something work, they make the very best products they possibly can. It's a demonstration against thoughtlessness and carelessness.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_95-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-95">[95]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Home_page">Home page</span></h3>
<p>The Apple website <a href="/wiki/Home_page" title="Home page">home page</a> has been used to commemorate, or pay tribute to, milestones and events outside of Apple's product offerings, including:
</p>
<ul><li>2020: <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women's Day">International Women's Day</a> <sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup></li>
<li>2020: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup></li>
<li>2019: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup></li>
<li>2018: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup></li>
<li>2017: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup></li>
<li>2016: <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali" title="Muhammad Ali">Muhammad Ali</a><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup></li>
<li>2016: <a href="/wiki/William_Campbell_(business_executive)" title="William Campbell (business executive)">Bill Campbell</a> (board member and friend)<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup></li>
<li>2016: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup></li>
<li>2015: <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup></li>
<li>2014: <a href="/wiki/Robin_Williams" title="Robin Williams">Robin Williams</a><sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup></li>
<li>2013: <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup></li>
<li>2012: <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a><sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup></li>
<li>2011: <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs" title="Steve Jobs">Steve Jobs</a><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup></li>
<li>2010: <a href="/wiki/Jerry_York_(businessman)" title="Jerry York (businessman)">Jerome B. York</a> (board member)<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup></li>
<li>2007: <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a> (board member; in honor of his <a href="/wiki/2007_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2007 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup></li>
<li>2005: <a href="/wiki/Rosa_Parks" title="Rosa Parks">Rosa Parks</a><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup></li>
<li>2003: <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Hines" title="Gregory Hines">Gregory Hines</a><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup></li>
<li>2001: <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup></li></ul><h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Headquarters">Headquarters</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">Apple Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Campus" title="Apple Campus">Apple Campus</a></div>
<p>Apple Inc.'s world corporate headquarters are located in the middle of <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>, at 1–6 <a href="/wiki/Infinite_Loop_(street)" class="mw-redirect" title="Infinite Loop (street)">Infinite Loop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cupertino,_California" title="Cupertino, California">Cupertino</a>, California. This Apple campus has six buildings that total 850,000 square feet (79,000 m<sup>2</sup>) and was built in 1993 by Sobrato Development Cos.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup></p><p>Apple has a satellite campus in neighboring <a href="/wiki/Sunnyvale,_California" title="Sunnyvale, California">Sunnyvale, California</a>, where it houses a testing and research laboratory.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/AppleInsider" class="mw-redirect" title="AppleInsider">AppleInsider</a> claimed in March 2014 that Apple has a top-secret facility for development of the SG5 electric vehicle project codenamed "Titan" under the shell company name <a href="/wiki/SixtyEight_Research" class="mw-redirect" title="SixtyEight Research">SixtyEight Research</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin:0 auto;overflow:hidden;width:right;max-width:808px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg" class="image" title="Panorama of the Auditorium in the Steve Jobs Theater at Apple Park in 2018"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg/800px-Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg" decoding="async" width="800" height="208" data-file-width="10332" data-file-height="2680"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 800px;height: 208px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg/800px-Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="800" data-height="208"> </span></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_Auditorium.jpg" title="File:Steve Jobs Theater - Auditorium.jpg"> </a></div>Panorama of the Auditorium in the <a href="/wiki/Steve_Jobs_Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Steve Jobs Theater">Steve Jobs Theater</a> at <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">Apple Park</a> in 2018</div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, Apple announced its intention to build a <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">second campus</a> in Cupertino about 1 mile (1.6 km) east of the current campus and next to Interstate 280.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> The new campus building has been designed by <a href="/wiki/Norman_Foster" class="mw-redirect" title="Norman Foster">Norman Foster</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup> The Cupertino City Council approved the proposed "spaceship" design campus on October 15, 2013, after a 2011 presentation by Jobs detailing the architectural design of the new building and its environs. The new campus is planned to house up to 13,000 employees in one central, four-storied, circular building surrounded by extensive landscape. It will feature a café with room for 3,000 sitting people and parking underground as well as in a parking structure. The 2.8 million square foot facility will also include Jobs's original designs for a fitness center and a corporate auditorium.<sup id="cite_ref-Green_light_for_spaceship_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Green_light_for_spaceship-414">[414]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg/220px-Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="4160" data-file-height="3120"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 165px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg/220px-Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="165" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Jobs_Theater_-_external.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>External view of the Steve Jobs Theater at <a href="/wiki/Apple_Park" title="Apple Park">Apple Park</a> in 2018</div></div></div>
<p>Apple has expanded its campuses in <a href="/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin, Texas</a>, concurrently with building Apple Park in Cupertino. The expansion consists of two locations, with one having 1.1 million square feet (100,000 m<sup>2</sup>) of workspace, and the other 216,000 square feet (20,100 m<sup>2</sup>).<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup> Apple will invest $1 billion to build the North Austin campus.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[416]</a></sup> At the biggest location, 6,000 employees work on technical support, manage Apple's network of suppliers to fulfill product shipments, aid in maintaining <a href="/wiki/ITunes_Store" title="ITunes Store">iTunes Store</a> and <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a>, handle economy, and continuously update <a href="/wiki/Apple_Maps" title="Apple Maps">Apple Maps</a> with new data. At its smaller campus, 500 engineers work on next-generation processor chips to run in future Apple products.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup></p><p>Apple's headquarters for Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EMEA) are located in <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a> in the south of <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc17782206_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc17782206-418">[418]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-humphries1_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-humphries1-419">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup> The facility, which opened in 1980, is Apple's first location outside of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup> Apple Sales International, which deals with all of Apple's international sales outside of the US, is located at Apple's campus in Cork<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> along with Apple Distribution International, which similarly deals with Apple's international distribution network.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup> On April 20, 2012, Apple added 500 new jobs at its European headquarters, increasing the total workforce from around 2,800 to 3,300 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-Green_light_for_spaceship_414-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Green_light_for_spaceship-414">[414]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-humphries1_419-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-humphries1-419">[419]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup> The company will build a new office block on its Hollyhill Campus to accommodate the additional staff.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> headquarters is at <a href="/wiki/Stockley_Park" title="Stockley Park">Stockley Park</a> on the outskirts of London.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup></p><p>In February 2015, Apple opened their new 180,000-square-foot headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Herzliya" title="Herzliya">Herzliya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>, designed to accommodate approximately 800 employees. This is Apple's third office located within Israel; the first, also in Herzliya, was obtained as part of the <a href="/wiki/Anobit" title="Anobit">Anobit</a> acquisition, and the other is a research center in <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup></p><p>In December 2015, Apple bought the 70,000-square-foot manufacturing facility in North San Jose previously used by <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Integrated" title="Maxim Integrated">Maxim Integrated</a> in an $18.2 million deal.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Stores">Stores</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">Apple Store</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg/220px-Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="3084" data-file-height="2322"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 166px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg/220px-Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="166" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Apple_store_fifth_avenue.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_(16015873508).jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_%2816015873508%29.jpg/220px-%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_%2816015873508%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 147px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_%2816015873508%29.jpg/220px-%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_%2816015873508%29.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="147" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%E8%A1%A8%E5%8F%83%E9%81%93_(16015873508).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Omotesando" class="mw-redirect" title="Omotesando">Omotesando</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a></div></div></div>
<p>The first Apple Stores were originally opened as two locations in May 2001 by then-<a href="/wiki/CEO" class="mw-redirect" title="CEO">CEO</a> Steve Jobs,<sup id="cite_ref-First_stores_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_stores-435">[435]</a></sup> after years of attempting but failing store-within-a-store concepts.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-436">[436]</a></sup> Seeing a need for improved retail presentation of the company's products, he began an effort in 1997 to revamp the retail program to get an improved relationship to consumers, and hired <a href="/wiki/Ron_Johnson_(businessman)" title="Ron Johnson (businessman)">Ron Johnson</a> in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_436-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-436">[436]</a></sup> Jobs relaunched Apple's online store in 1997,<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup> and opened the first two physical stores in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-First_stores_435-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-First_stores-435">[435]</a></sup> The media initially speculated that Apple would fail,<sup id="cite_ref-fortune-best-retailer_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-best-retailer-438">[438]</a></sup> but its stores were highly successful, bypassing the sales numbers of competing nearby stores and within three years reached US$1 billion in annual sales, becoming the fastest retailer in history to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-fortune-best-retailer_438-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortune-best-retailer-438">[438]</a></sup> Over the years, Apple has expanded the number of retail locations and its geographical coverage, with 499 stores across 22 countries worldwide as of December 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> Strong product sales have placed Apple among the top-tier retail stores, with sales over $16 billion globally in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-440">[440]</a></sup></p><p>In May 2016, <a href="/wiki/Angela_Ahrendts" title="Angela Ahrendts">Angela Ahrendts</a>, Apple's then Senior Vice President of Retail, unveiled a significantly redesigned Apple Store in <a href="/wiki/Union_Square,_San_Francisco" title="Union Square, San Francisco">Union Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>, featuring large glass doors for the entry, open spaces, and rebranded rooms. In addition to purchasing products, consumers can get advice and help from "Creative Pros" – individuals with specialized knowledge of creative arts; get product support in a tree-lined Genius Grove; and attend sessions, conferences and community events,<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> with Ahrendts commenting that the goal is to make Apple Stores into "town squares", a place where people naturally meet up and spend time.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup> The new design will be applied to all Apple Stores worldwide,<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup> a process that has seen stores temporarily relocate<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> or close.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup></p><p>Many Apple Stores are located inside shopping malls, but Apple has built several stand-alone "flagship" stores in high-profile locations.<sup id="cite_ref-MacRumors_stores_436-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacRumors_stores-436">[436]</a></sup> It has been granted design <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">patents</a> and received architectural awards for its stores' designs and construction, specifically for its use of glass staircases and cubes.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup> The success of Apple Stores have had significant influence over other consumer electronics retailers, who have lost traffic, control and profits due to a perceived higher quality of service and products at Apple Stores.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> Apple's notable brand loyalty among consumers causes long lines of hundreds of people at new Apple Store openings or product releases.<sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_1_371-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_1-371">[371]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_2_372-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_2-372">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_3_373-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_3-373">[373]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brand_loyalty_4_374-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brand_loyalty_4-374">[374]</a></sup> Due to the popularity of the brand, Apple receives a large number of job applications, many of which come from young workers.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_440-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-440">[440]</a></sup> Although Apple Store employees receive above-average pay, are offered money toward education and health care, and receive product discounts,<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_440-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-440">[440]</a></sup> there are limited or no paths of career advancement.<sup id="cite_ref-retail_army_440-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-retail_army-440">[440]</a></sup> A May 2016 report with an anonymous retail employee highlighted a <a href="/wiki/Hostile_work_environment" title="Hostile work environment">hostile work environment</a> with harassment from customers, intense internal criticism, and a lack of significant bonuses for securing major business contracts.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup></p><p>Due to the <a href="/wiki/2019-20_coronavirus_pandemic" class="mw-redirect" title="2019-20 coronavirus pandemic">2019-20 coronavirus pandemic</a> outbreak, Apple announced that they will be closing its stores outside China until March 27, 2020. Despite the stores being closed, hourly workers will continue to be paid. Workers across the company will be allowed to work remotely if their jobs permit it.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup> On March 24, 2020, in a memo, Senior Vice President of People and Retail Deirdre O’Brien announced that some of its retail stores are expected to reopen at the beginning of April.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup></p>
</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(4)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_affairs">Corporate affairs</span></h2><section class="mf-section-4 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-4">
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple">List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Braeburn_Capital" title="Braeburn Capital">Braeburn Capital</a>, and <a href="/wiki/FileMaker_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="FileMaker Inc.">FileMaker Inc.</a></div>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_culture">Corporate culture</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg/220px-Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="1264" data-file-height="944"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 164px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg/220px-Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="164" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Wozniak_and_Andy_Hertzfeld_1985.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andy_Hertzfeld" title="Andy Hertzfeld">Andy Hertzfeld</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Apple_User_Group_Connection" title="Apple User Group Connection">Apple User Group Connection</a> club in 1985</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png/280px-Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="322" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="796" data-file-height="916"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 280px;height: 322px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png/280px-Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" data-alt="" data-width="280" data-height="322" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Colleges_with_the_most_alumni_at_Apple.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Universities with the most alumni at Apple</div></div></div>
<p>Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporate culture">corporate culture</a>. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> company. By the time of the <a href="/wiki/1984_(advertisement)" title="1984 (advertisement)">"1984"</a> television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup> According to a 2011 report in <i><a href="/wiki/Fortune_(magazine)" title="Fortune (magazine)">Fortune</a>,</i> this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.<sup id="cite_ref-Fortune1_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune1-454">[454]</a></sup></p><p>As the company has grown and been led by a series of differently opinionated chief executives, it has arguably lost some of its original character. Nonetheless, it has maintained a reputation for fostering individuality and excellence that reliably attracts talented workers, particularly after Jobs returned to the company. Numerous Apple employees have stated that projects without Jobs's involvement often took longer than projects with it.<sup id="cite_ref-cultofmacwork_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cultofmacwork-455">[455]</a></sup></p><p>To recognize the best of its employees, Apple created the Apple Fellows program which awards individuals who make extraordinary technical or leadership contributions to <a href="/wiki/Personal_computing" class="mw-redirect" title="Personal computing">personal computing</a> while at the company. The Apple Fellowship has so far been awarded to individuals including <a href="/wiki/Bill_Atkinson" title="Bill Atkinson">Bill Atkinson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_456-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-456">[456]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Capps" title="Steve Capps">Steve Capps</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rod_Holt" title="Rod Holt">Rod Holt</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_456-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-456">[456]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alan_Kay" title="Alan Kay">Alan Kay</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-458">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guy_Kawasaki" title="Guy Kawasaki">Guy Kawasaki</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_458-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-458">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[460]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al_Alcorn" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Alcorn">Al Alcorn</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[461]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Don_Norman" title="Don Norman">Don Norman</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-yoyow_458-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yoyow-458">[458]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rich_Page" title="Rich Page">Rich Page</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_456-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-456">[456]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Steve_Wozniak" title="Steve Wozniak">Steve Wozniak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hertzfeld_456-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hertzfeld-456">[456]</a></sup></p><p>At Apple, employees are intended to be specialists who are not exposed to functions outside their area of expertise. Jobs saw this as a means of having "best-in-class" employees in every role. For instance, <a href="/wiki/Ron_Johnson_(businessman)" title="Ron Johnson (businessman)">Ron Johnson</a>—Senior Vice President of Retail Operations until November 1, 2011—was responsible for site selection, in-store service, and store layout, yet had no control of the inventory in his stores. This was done by Tim Cook, who had a background in supply-chain management.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-462">[462]</a></sup> Apple is known for strictly enforcing accountability. Each project has a "directly responsible individual" or "DRI" in Apple jargon.<sup id="cite_ref-Fortune1_454-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune1-454">[454]</a></sup> As an example, when iOS senior vice president <a href="/wiki/Scott_Forstall" title="Scott Forstall">Scott Forstall</a> refused to sign Apple's official apology for numerous errors in the redesigned <a href="/wiki/Apple_Maps" title="Apple Maps">Maps app</a>, he was forced to resign.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[463]</a></sup> Unlike other major U.S. companies, Apple provides a relatively simple compensation policy for executives that does not include perks enjoyed by other CEOs like country club fees or private use of company aircraft. The company typically grants stock options to executives every other year.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[464]</a></sup></p><p>In 2015, Apple had 110,000 full-time employees. This increased to 116,000 full-time employees the next year, a notable hiring decrease, largely due to its first revenue decline. Apple does not specify how many of its employees work in retail, though its 2014 <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">SEC</a> filing put the number at approximately half of its employee base.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[465]</a></sup> In September 2017, Apple announced that it had over 123,000 full-time employees.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[466]</a></sup></p><p>Apple has a strong culture of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_secrecy" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporate secrecy">corporate secrecy</a>, and has an anti-<a href="/wiki/News_leak" title="News leak">leak</a> Global Security team that recruits from the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">National Security Agency</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service" title="United States Secret Service">United States Secret Service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[467]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[469]</a></sup></p><p>In December 2017, <a href="/wiki/Glassdoor" title="Glassdoor">Glassdoor</a> said Apple was the 48th best place to work, having originally entered at rank 19 in 2009, peaking at rank 10 in 2012, and falling down the ranks in subsequent years.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[470]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[471]</a></sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Lack_of_innovation">Lack of innovation</span></h4>
<p>An editorial article in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Verge" title="The Verge">The Verge</a></i> in September 2016 by technology journalist Thomas Ricker explored some of the public's perceived lack of innovation at Apple in recent years, specifically stating that Samsung has "matched and even surpassed Apple in terms of smartphone industrial design" and citing the belief that Apple is incapable of producing another breakthrough moment in technology with its products. He goes on to write that the criticism focuses on individual pieces of hardware rather than the ecosystem as a whole, stating "Yes, iteration is boring. But it's also how Apple does business. [...] It enters a new market and then refines and refines and continues refining until it yields a success". He acknowledges that people are wishing for the "excitement of revolution", but argues that people want "the comfort that comes with harmony". Furthermore, he writes that "a device is only the starting point of an experience that will ultimately be ruled by the ecosystem in which it was spawned", referring to how decent hardware products can still fail without a proper ecosystem (specifically mentioning that <a href="/wiki/Walkman" title="Walkman">Walkman</a> didn't have an ecosystem to keep users from leaving once something better came along), but how Apple devices in different hardware segments are able to communicate and cooperate through the <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a> cloud service with features including Universal Clipboard (in which text copied on one device can be pasted on a different device) as well as inter-connected device functionality including Auto Unlock (in which an <a href="/wiki/Apple_Watch" title="Apple Watch">Apple Watch</a> can unlock a <a href="/wiki/Macintosh" title="Macintosh">Mac</a> in close proximity). He argues that Apple's ecosystem is its greatest innovation.<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[472]</a></sup></p><p><i>The Wall Street Journal</i> reported in June 2017 that Apple's increased reliance on <a href="/wiki/Siri" title="Siri">Siri</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Virtual_assistant_(artificial_intelligence)" class="mw-redirect" title="Virtual assistant (artificial intelligence)">virtual personal assistant</a>, has raised questions about how much Apple can actually accomplish in terms of functionality. Whereas <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a> make use of <a href="/wiki/Big_data" title="Big data">big data</a> and analyze customer information to personalize results, Apple has a strong <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc.#Privacy_stance" title="Apple Inc.">pro-privacy stance</a>, intentionally not retaining user data. "Siri is a textbook of <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">leading on something in tech</a> and then losing an edge despite having all the money and the talent and sitting in Silicon Valley", Holger Mueller, a technology analyst, told the <i>Journal</i>. The report further claims that development on Siri has suffered due to team members and executives leaving the company for competitors, a lack of ambitious goals, and shifting strategies. Though switching Siri's functions to <a href="/wiki/Machine_learning" title="Machine learning">machine learning</a> and <a href="/wiki/Algorithm" title="Algorithm">algorithms</a>, which dramatically cut its error rate, the company reportedly still failed to anticipate the popularity of Amazon's <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Echo" title="Amazon Echo">Echo</a>, which features the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Alexa" title="Amazon Alexa">Alexa</a> personal assistant. Improvements to Siri stalled, executives clashed, and there were disagreements over the restrictions imposed on third-party app interactions. While Apple acquired an England-based startup specializing in conversational assistants, Google's <a href="/wiki/Google_Assistant" title="Google Assistant">Assistant</a> had already become capable of helping users select Wi-Fi networks by voice, and Siri was lagging in functionality.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[474]</a></sup></p><p>In December 2017, two articles from <i>The Verge</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/ZDNet" title="ZDNet">ZDNet</a></i> debated what had been a particularly devastating week for Apple's macOS and iOS software platforms. The former had experienced a severe security vulnerability, in which Macs running the then-latest <a href="/wiki/MacOS_High_Sierra" title="MacOS High Sierra">macOS High Sierra</a> software were vulnerable to a bug that let anyone gain administrator privileges by entering "root" as the username in system prompts, leaving the password field empty and twice clicking "unlock", gaining full access.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[475]</a></sup> The bug was publicly disclosed on <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>, rather than through proper <a href="/wiki/Bug_bounty_program" title="Bug bounty program">bug bounty programs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[476]</a></sup> Apple released a security fix within a day and issued an apology, stating that "regrettably we stumbled" in regards to the security of the latest updates.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[477]</a></sup> After installing the security patch, however, file sharing was broken for users, with Apple releasing a support document with instructions to separately fix that issue.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[478]</a></sup> Though Apple publicly stated the promise of "auditing our development processes to help prevent this from happening again", users who installed the security update while running the older 10.13.0 version of the High Sierra operating system rather than the then-newest 10.13.1 release experienced that the "root" security vulnerability was re-introduced, and persisted even after fully updating their systems.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[479]</a></sup> On iOS, a date bug caused iOS devices that received local app notifications at 12:15am on December 2, 2017 to repeatedly restart.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[480]</a></sup> Users were recommended to turn off notifications for their apps.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[481]</a></sup> Apple quickly released an update, done during the nighttime in Cupertino, California time<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[482]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[483]</a></sup> and outside of their usual software release window,<sup id="cite_ref-verge_bad_week_484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge_bad_week-484">[484]</a></sup> with one of the headlining features of the update needing to be delayed for a few days.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485">[485]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[486]</a></sup> The combined problems of the week on both macOS and iOS caused <i>The Verge</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Tom Warren to call it a "nightmare" for Apple's software engineers and described it as a significant lapse in Apple's ability to protect its more than 1 billion devices.<sup id="cite_ref-verge_bad_week_484-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-verge_bad_week-484">[484]</a></sup> <i>ZDNet</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Adrian Kingsley-Hughes wrote that "it's hard to not come away from the last week with the feeling that Apple is slipping".<sup id="cite_ref-zdnet_rotten_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zdnet_rotten-487">[487]</a></sup> Kingsley-Hughes also concluded his piece by referencing an earlier article, in which he wrote that "As much as I don't want to bring up the tired old 'Apple wouldn't have done this under Steve Jobs's watch' trope, a lot of what's happening at Apple lately is different from what they came to expect under Jobs. Not to say that things didn't go wrong under his watch, but product announcements and launches felt a lot tighter for sure, as did the overall quality of what Apple was releasing." He did, however, also acknowledge that such failures "may indeed have happened" with Jobs in charge, though returning to the previous praise for his demands of quality, stating "it's almost guaranteed that given his personality that heads would have rolled, which limits future failures".<sup id="cite_ref-zdnet_rotten_487-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zdnet_rotten-487">[487]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Manufacturing">Manufacturing</span></h3>
<p>The company's manufacturing, procurement, and logistics enable it to execute massive product launches without having to maintain large, profit-sapping inventories. In 2011, Apple's profit margins were 40 percent, compared with between 10 and 20 percent for most other hardware companies. Cook's catchphrase to describe his focus on the company's operational arm is: "Nobody wants to buy sour milk".<sup id="cite_ref-supply_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-supply-172">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[488]</a></sup></p><p>During the Mac's early history Apple generally refused to adopt prevailing industry standards for hardware, instead creating their own.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[489]</a></sup> This trend was largely reversed in the late 1990s, beginning with Apple's adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Peripheral_Component_Interconnect" class="mw-redirect" title="Peripheral Component Interconnect">PCI</a> bus in the <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_7500" title="Power Macintosh 7500">7500</a>/<a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_8500" title="Power Macintosh 8500">8500</a>/<a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh_9500" title="Power Macintosh 9500">9500</a> <a href="/wiki/Power_Macintosh" title="Power Macintosh">Power Macs</a>. Apple has since joined the industry standards groups to influence the future direction of technology standards such as <a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accelerated_Graphics_Port" title="Accelerated Graphics Port">AGP</a>, <a href="/wiki/HyperTransport" title="HyperTransport">HyperTransport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a>, <a href="/wiki/NVM_Express" title="NVM Express">NVMe</a>, <a href="/wiki/PCI_Express" title="PCI Express">PCIe</a> and others in its products. <a href="/wiki/FireWire" class="mw-redirect" title="FireWire">FireWire</a> is an Apple-originated standard that was widely adopted across the industry after it was standardized as <a href="/wiki/IEEE_1394" title="IEEE 1394">IEEE 1394</a> and is a legally mandated port in all Cable TV boxes in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[490]</a></sup></p><p>Apple has gradually expanded its efforts in getting its products into the Indian market. In July 2012, during a conference call with investors, CEO <a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> said that he "[loves] India", but that Apple saw larger opportunities outside the region.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[491]</a></sup> India's requirement that 30% of products sold be manufactured in the country was described as "really adds cost to getting product to market".<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[492]</a></sup> In October 2013, Indian Apple executives unveiled a plan for selling devices through instalment plans and <a href="/wiki/Store-within-a-store" title="Store-within-a-store">store-within-a-store</a> concepts, in an effort to expand further into the market. The news followed Cook's acknowledgment of the country in July when sales results showed that iPhone sales in India grew 400% during the second quarter of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[493]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">[494]</a></sup> In March 2016, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times_of_India" title="The Times of India">The Times of India</a></i> reported that Apple had sought permission from the Indian government to sell <a href="/wiki/Refurbishment_(electronics)" title="Refurbishment (electronics)">refurbished</a> iPhones in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[496]</a></sup> However, two months later, the application was rejected, citing official country policy.<sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[497]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[498]</a></sup> In May 2016, Apple opened an iOS app development center in <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a> and a maps development office for 4,000 staff in Hyderabad.<sup id="cite_ref-499" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-499">[499]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[501]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[502]</a></sup> In February 2017, Apple once again requested permission to sell used iPhones in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[503]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[504]</a></sup> The same month, <i><a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P." title="Bloomberg L.P.">Bloomberg</a></i> reported that Apple was close to receiving permission to open its first retail store in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[505]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[506]</a></sup> In March, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Apple would begin manufacturing iPhone models in India "over the next two months",<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[507]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[508]</a></sup> and in May, the <i>Journal</i> wrote that an Apple manufacturer had begun production of <a href="/wiki/IPhone_SE" title="IPhone SE">iPhone SE</a> in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[509]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[510]</a></sup> while Apple told <i><a href="/wiki/CNBC" title="CNBC">CNBC</a></i> that the manufacturing was for a "small number" of units.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[511]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> reported in December 2017, that Apple and the Indian government were clashing over planned increases to import taxes for components used in mobile phone production, with Apple having engaged in talks with government officials to try to delay the plans, but the Indian government sticking to its policies of no exemptions to its "<a href="/wiki/Make_in_India" title="Make in India">Make in India</a>" initiative.<sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">[512]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[513]</a></sup> The import tax increases went into effect a few days later, with Apple being hurt the most out of all phone manufacturers, having nine of out ten phones imported into the country, whereas main smartphone competitor <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> produces almost all of its devices locally.<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[514]</a></sup> In April 2019, Apple initiated manufacturing of iPhone 7 at its <a href="/wiki/Bengaluru" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengaluru">Bengaluru</a> facility, keeping in mind demand from local customers even as they seek more incentives from the government of India.<sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[515]</a></sup> At the beginning of 2020, Tim Cook announced that Apple schedules the opening of its first physical outlet in India for 2021, while an online store is to be launched by the end of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[516]</a></sup></p><p>In May 2017, the company announced a $1 billion funding project for "advanced manufacturing" in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517">[517]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[518]</a></sup> and subsequently invested $200 million in <a href="/wiki/Corning_Inc." title="Corning Inc.">Corning Inc.</a>, a manufacturer of toughened <a href="/wiki/Gorilla_Glass" title="Gorilla Glass">Gorilla Glass</a> technology used in its <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> devices.<sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519">[519]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-520" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-520">[520]</a></sup> The following December, Apple's chief operating officer, <a href="/wiki/Jeff_Williams_(Apple)" title="Jeff Williams (Apple)">Jeff Williams</a>, told <i>CNBC</i> that the "$1 billion" amount was "absolutely not" the final limit on its spending, elaborating that "We're not thinking in terms of a fund limit. ... We're thinking about, where are the opportunities across the U.S. to help nurture companies that are making the advanced technology — and the advanced manufacturing that goes with that — that quite frankly is essential to our innovation".<sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521">[521]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[522]</a></sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Labor_practices">Labor practices</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Apple_Inc.#Labor_practices" title="Criticism of Apple Inc.">Criticism of Apple Inc. § Labor practices</a></div>
<p>The company advertised its products as being made in America until the late 1990s; however, as a result of <a href="/wiki/Outsourcing" title="Outsourcing">outsourcing</a> initiatives in the 2000s, almost all of its manufacturing is now handled abroad.
