According to a report by <i>The New York Times</i>, Apple insiders "believe the vast scale of overseas factories, as well as the flexibility, diligence and industrial skills of foreign workers, have so outpaced their American counterparts that "Made in the U.S.A." is no longer a viable option for most Apple products".<sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[523]</a></sup></p><p>In 2006, the <i><a href="/wiki/Mail_on_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Mail on Sunday">Mail on Sunday</a></i> reported on the working conditions of the Chinese factories where contract manufacturers <a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inventec" title="Inventec">Inventec</a> produced the iPod.<sup id="cite_ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524">[524]</a></sup> The article stated that one complex of factories that assembled the iPod and other items had over 200,000 workers living and working within it. Employees regularly worked more than 60 hours per week and made around $100 per month. A little over half of the workers' earnings was required to pay for rent and food from the company.<sup id="cite_ref-wpsweatshop_525-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wpsweatshop-525">[525]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526">[526]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">[527]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">[528]</a></sup></p><p>Apple immediately launched an investigation after the 2006 media report, and worked with their manufacturers to ensure acceptable working conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[529]</a></sup> In 2007, Apple started yearly audits of all its suppliers regarding <a href="/wiki/Worker%27s_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Worker's rights">worker's rights</a>, slowly raising standards and pruning suppliers that did not comply. Yearly progress reports have been published since 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530">[530]</a></sup> In 2011, Apple admitted that its suppliers' child labor practices in China had worsened.<sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531">[531]</a></sup></p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Foxconn_suicides" title="Foxconn suicides">Foxconn suicides</a> occurred between January and November 2010, when 18<sup id="cite_ref-tian_532-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tian-532">[532]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a> (Chinese: 富士康) employees attempted <a href="/wiki/Suicide" title="Suicide">suicide</a>, resulting in 14 deaths—the company was the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, for clients including Apple, at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-tian_532-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tian-532">[532]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-scmpreport_533-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scmpreport-533">[533]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reuters3_534-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters3-534">[534]</a></sup> The suicides drew media attention, and employment practices at Foxconn were investigated by Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ-Foxconn_535-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-Foxconn-535">[535]</a></sup> Apple issued a public statement about the suicides, and company spokesperson Steven Dowling said:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"><blockquote class="templatequote" style="font-size:100%"><p>[Apple is] saddened and upset by the recent suicides at Foxconn ... A team from Apple is independently evaluating the steps they are taking to address these tragic events and we will continue our ongoing inspections of the facilities where our products are made.<sup id="cite_ref-Huff_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huff-536">[536]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The statement was released after the results from the company's probe into its suppliers' labor practices were published in early 2010. Foxconn was not specifically named in the report, but Apple identified a series of serious labor violations of labor laws, including Apple's own rules, and some child labor existed in a number of factories.<sup id="cite_ref-Huff_536-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huff-536">[536]</a></sup> Apple committed to the implementation of changes following the suicides.<sup id="cite_ref-Fire_537-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fire-537">[537]</a></sup></p><p>Also in 2010, workers in China planned to sue iPhone contractors over poisoning by a cleaner used to clean LCD screens. One worker claimed that he and his coworkers had not been informed of possible occupational illnesses.<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">[538]</a></sup> After a high suicide rate in a Foxconn facility in China making iPads and iPhones, albeit a lower rate than that of China as a whole,<sup id="cite_ref-539" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-539">[539]</a></sup> workers were forced to sign a legally binding document guaranteeing that they would not kill themselves.<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">[540]</a></sup> Workers in factories producing Apple products have also been exposed to n-<a href="/wiki/Hexane" title="Hexane">hexane</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Neurotoxin" title="Neurotoxin">neurotoxin</a> that is a cheaper alternative than alcohol for cleaning the products.<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541">[541]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-542" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-542">[542]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">[543]</a></sup></p><p>A 2014 BBC investigation found excessive hours and other problems persisted, despite Apple's promise to reform factory practice after the 2010 Foxconn suicides. The Pegatron factory was once again the subject of review, as reporters gained access to the working conditions inside through recruitment as employees. While the BBC maintained that the experiences of its reporters showed that labor violations were continuing since 2010, Apple publicly disagreed with the BBC and stated: "We are aware of no other company doing as much as Apple to ensure fair and safe working conditions".<sup id="cite_ref-Fire_537-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fire-537">[537]</a></sup></p><p>In December 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Global_Labour_and_Human_Rights" title="Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights">Institute for Global Labour and Human Rights</a> published a report which documented inhumane conditions for the 15,000 workers at a Zhen Ding Technology factory in Shenzhen, China, which serves as a major supplier of circuit boards for Apple's iPhone and iPad. According to the report, workers are pressured into 65-hour work weeks which leaves them so exhausted that they often sleep during lunch breaks. They are also made to reside in "primitive, dark and filthy dorms" where they sleep "on plywood, with six to ten workers in each crowded room." Omnipresent security personnel also routinely harass and beat the workers.<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544">[544]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-545">[545]</a></sup></p><p>In 2019, there were reports stating that some of Foxconn's managers had used rejected parts to build iPhones, and that Apple was investigating the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">[546]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_practices_and_initiatives">Environmental practices and initiatives</span></h3>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Apple_Energy">Apple Energy</span></h4>
<p>Apple Energy, LLC is a wholly owned subsidiary of Apple Inc. that sells <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar energy</a>. As of June 6, 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple's solar farms in California and Nevada have been declared to provide 217.9 megawatts of solar generation capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">[547]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[548]</a></sup> In addition to the company's solar energy production, Apple has received regulatory approval to construct a <a href="/wiki/Landfill_gas_utilization" title="Landfill gas utilization">landfill gas energy plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a>. Apple will use the <a href="/wiki/Methane" title="Methane">methane</a> emissions to generate electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[549]</a></sup> Apple's North Carolina data center is already powered entirely with energy from renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">[550]</a></sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_and_resources">Energy and resources</span></h4>
<p>Following a <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> protest, Apple released a statement on April 17, 2012, committing to ending its use of coal and shifting to 100% renewable clean energy.<sup id="cite_ref-After_Greenpeace_Protests,_Apple_Promises_to_Dump_Coal_Power_551-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-After_Greenpeace_Protests,_Apple_Promises_to_Dump_Coal_Power-551">[551]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Powering_Our_Facilities_with_Clean,_Renewable_Energy_552-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Powering_Our_Facilities_with_Clean,_Renewable_Energy-552">[552]</a></sup> By 2013, Apple was using 100% renewable energy to power their data centers. Overall, 75% of the company's power came from clean renewable sources.<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">[553]</a></sup></p><p>In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Climate_Counts" title="Climate Counts">Climate Counts</a>, a nonprofit organization dedicated to directing consumers toward the greenest companies, gave Apple a score of 52 points out of a possible 100, which puts Apple in their top category "Striding".<sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[554]</a></sup> This was an increase from May 2008, when Climate Counts only gave Apple 11 points out of 100, which placed the company last among electronics companies, at which time Climate Counts also labeled Apple with a "stuck icon", adding that Apple at the time was "a choice to avoid for the climate-conscious consumer".<sup id="cite_ref-iwclimate_555-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iwclimate-555">[555]</a></sup></p><p>In May 2015, Greenpeace evaluated the state of the Green Internet and commended Apple on their environmental practices saying, "Apple's commitment to renewable energy has helped set a new bar for the industry, illustrating in very concrete terms that a 100% renewable Internet is within its reach, and providing several models of intervention for other companies that want to build a sustainable Internet."<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">[556]</a></sup></p><p>As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple states that 100% of its U.S. operations run on <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a>, 100% of Apple's <a href="/wiki/Data_center" title="Data center">data centers</a> run on renewable energy and 93% of Apple's global operations run on renewable energy.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">[557]</a></sup> However, the facilities are connected to the local <a href="/wiki/Electrical_grid" title="Electrical grid">grid</a> which usually contains a mix of fossil and renewable sources, so Apple <a href="/wiki/Carbon_offset" title="Carbon offset">carbon offsets</a> its electricity use.<sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-558">[558]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559">[559]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Product_Environmental_Assessment_Tool" title="Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool">Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool</a> (EPEAT) allows consumers to see the effect a product has on the environment. Each product receives a Gold, Silver, or Bronze rank depending on its efficiency and sustainability. Every Apple <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">tablet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laptop" title="Laptop">notebook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desktop_computer" title="Desktop computer">desktop computer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Computer_monitor" title="Computer monitor">display</a> that EPEAT ranks achieves a Gold rating, the highest possible. Although Apple's data centers recycle water 35 times,<sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560">[560]</a></sup> the increased activity in retail, corporate and data centers also increase the amount of water use to 573 million US gal (2.2 million m<sup>3</sup>) in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-561">[561]</a></sup></p><p>During an event on March 21, 2016, Apple provided a status update on its environmental initiative to be 100% renewable in all of its worldwide operations. <a href="/wiki/Lisa_P._Jackson" title="Lisa P. Jackson">Lisa P. Jackson</a>, Apple's vice president of Environment, Policy and Social Initiatives who reports directly to CEO, Tim Cook, announced that as of March 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 93% of Apple's worldwide operations are powered with renewable energy. Also featured was the company's efforts to use sustainable paper in their product packaging; 99% of all paper used by Apple in the product packaging comes from <a href="/wiki/Post-consumer" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-consumer">post-consumer</a> <a href="/wiki/Recycle" class="mw-redirect" title="Recycle">recycled</a> paper or sustainably managed forests, as the company continues its move to all paper packaging for all of its products.<sup id="cite_ref-562" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-562">[562]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563">[563]</a></sup> Apple working in partnership with <a href="/wiki/The_Conservation_Fund" title="The Conservation Fund">Conservation Fund</a>, have preserved 36,000 acres of working forests in <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a>. Another partnership announced is with the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wildlife Fund</a> to preserve up to 1,000,000 acres (4,000 km<sup>2</sup>) of forests in China. Featured was the company's installation of a 40 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MW</a> <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar power plant</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a> province of <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> that was tailor-made to coexist with the indigenous yaks that eat hay produced on the land, by raising the panels to be several feet off of the ground so the yaks and their feed would be unharmed grazing beneath the array. This installation alone compensates for more than all of the energy used in Apple's Stores and Offices in the whole of China, negating the company's energy carbon footprint in the country. In <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Apple has worked with the Singaporean government to cover the rooftops of 800 buildings in the city-state with solar panels allowing Apple's Singapore operations to be run on 100% renewable energy. Liam was introduced to the world, an advanced robotic disassembler and sorter designed by Apple Engineers in California specifically for recycling outdated or broken iPhones. Reuses and recycles parts from traded in products.<sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564">[564]</a></sup></p><p>Apple announced on August 16, 2016, that Lens Technology, one of its major suppliers in China, has committed to power all its <a href="/wiki/Glass_production" title="Glass production">glass production</a> for Apple with 100 percent renewable energy by 2018. The commitment is a large step in Apple's efforts to help manufacturers lower their carbon footprint in China.<sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-565">[565]</a></sup> Apple also announced that all 14 of its final assembly sites in China are now compliant with <a href="/wiki/UL_(safety_organization)" title="UL (safety organization)">UL's</a> Zero Waste to Landfill validation. The standard, which started in January 2015, certifies that all manufacturing waste is <a href="/wiki/Reuse" title="Reuse">reused</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recycled" class="mw-redirect" title="Recycled">recycled</a>, <a href="/wiki/Compost" title="Compost">composted</a>, or converted into energy (when necessary). Since the program began, nearly, 140,000 metric tons of waste have been diverted from <a href="/wiki/Landfill" title="Landfill">landfills</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-566" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-566">[566]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (November 2017)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Toxins">Toxins</span></h4>
<p>Following further campaigns by Greenpeace,<sup id="cite_ref-itox_567-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itox-567">[567]</a></sup> in 2008, Apple became the first electronics manufacturer to fully eliminate all <a href="/wiki/Polyvinyl_chloride" title="Polyvinyl chloride">polyvinyl chloride</a> (PVC) and <a href="/wiki/Brominated_flame_retardant" title="Brominated flame retardant">brominated flame retardants</a> (BFRs) in its complete product line.<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568">[568]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569">[569]</a></sup> In June 2007, Apple began replacing the <a href="/wiki/Cold_cathode" title="Cold cathode">cold cathode</a> fluorescent lamp (CCFL) backlit <a href="/wiki/LCD" class="mw-redirect" title="LCD">LCD</a> displays in its computers with <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">mercury</a>-free <a href="/wiki/LED-backlit_LCD_display" class="mw-redirect" title="LED-backlit LCD display">LED-backlit LCD displays</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arsenic" title="Arsenic">arsenic</a>-free glass, starting with the upgraded <a href="/wiki/MacBook_Pro" title="MacBook Pro">MacBook Pro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_570-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-570">[570]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-agreenapple_571-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agreenapple-571">[571]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-green_notebooks_572-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-green_notebooks-572">[572]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573">[573]</a></sup> Apple offers comprehensive and transparent information about the <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_equivalent" title="Carbon dioxide equivalent">CO<sub>2</sub>e</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas#Direct_greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas">emissions</a>, materials, and <a href="/wiki/Electric_energy_consumption" title="Electric energy consumption">electrical usage</a> concerning every product they currently produce or have sold in the past (and which they have enough data needed to produce the report), in their portfolio on their homepage. Allowing consumers to make informed purchasing decisions on the products they offer for sale.<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574">[574]</a></sup> In June 2009, Apple's <a href="/wiki/IPhone_3GS" title="IPhone 3GS">iPhone 3GS</a> was free of PVC, arsenic, and BFRs.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_570-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-570">[570]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575">[575]</a></sup> All Apple products now have mercury-free LED-backlit LCD displays, arsenic-free glass, and non-PVC cables. All Apple products have EPEAT Gold status and beat the latest Energy Star guidelines in each product's respective regulatory category.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple-environmental-news_570-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple-environmental-news-570">[570]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576">[576]</a></sup></p><p>In November 2011, Apple was featured in Greenpeace's Guide to Greener Electronics, which ranks electronics manufacturers on sustainability, <a href="/wiki/Climate_and_energy" title="Climate and energy">climate and energy</a> policy, and how "green" their products are. The company ranked fourth of fifteen electronics companies (moving up five places from the previous year) with a score of 4.6/10.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">[577]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-578" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-578">[578]</a></sup> Greenpeace praises Apple's <a href="/wiki/Sustainability_metrics_and_indices" title="Sustainability metrics and indices">sustainability</a>, noting that the company exceeded its 70% global recycling goal in 2010. It continues to score well on the products rating with all Apple products now being free of PVC plastic and BFRs. However, the guide criticizes Apple on the Energy criteria for not seeking external verification of its greenhouse gas emissions data and for not setting out any targets to reduce emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579">[579]</a></sup> In January 2012, Apple requested that its cable maker, Volex, begin producing <a href="/wiki/Low_smoke_zero_halogen" title="Low smoke zero halogen">halogen-free</a> <a href="/wiki/USB" title="USB">USB</a> and power cables.<sup id="cite_ref-580" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-580">[580]</a></sup></p>
<h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Green_bonds">Green bonds</span></h4>
<p>In February 2016, Apple issued a US$1.5 billion <a href="/wiki/Green_bond" class="mw-redirect" title="Green bond">green bond</a> (climate bond), the first ever of its kind by a U.S. tech company. The green bond proceeds are dedicated to the financing of environmental projects.<sup id="cite_ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581">[581]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Finance">Finance</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple">List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple</a></div>
<p>Apple is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_information_technology_companies" class="mw-redirect" title="List of the largest information technology companies">world's largest information technology company</a> by revenue, the world's largest technology company by <a href="/wiki/Asset" title="Asset">total assets</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-582" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-582">[582]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Mobile_phone#By_manufacturer" title="Mobile phone">world's second-largest mobile phone manufacturer</a> after <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583">[583]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-584" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-584">[584]</a></sup></p><p>In its fiscal year ending in September 2011, Apple Inc. reported a total of $108 billion in annual revenues—a significant increase from its 2010 revenues of $65 billion—and nearly $82 billion in <a href="/wiki/Reserve_(accounting)" title="Reserve (accounting)">cash reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-585" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-585">[585]</a></sup> On March 19, 2012, Apple announced plans for a $2.65-per-share <a href="/wiki/Dividend" title="Dividend">dividend</a> beginning in fourth quarter of 2012, per approval by their board of directors.<sup id="cite_ref-dividendfaq_586-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dividendfaq-586">[586]</a></sup></p><p>The company's worldwide annual revenue in 2013 totaled $170 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587">[587]</a></sup> In May 2013, Apple entered the top ten of the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500"><i>Fortune</i> 500</a> list of companies for the first time, rising 11 places above its 2012 ranking to take the sixth position.<sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588">[588]</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple has around US$234 billion of cash and marketable securities, of which 90% is located outside the United States for tax purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-b200_589-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b200-589">[589]</a></sup></p><p>Apple amassed 65% of all profits made by the eight largest worldwide smartphone manufacturers in quarter one of 2014, according to a report by <a href="/wiki/Canaccord_Genuity" title="Canaccord Genuity">Canaccord Genuity</a>. In the first quarter of 2015, the company garnered 92% of all earnings.<sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590">[590]</a></sup></p><p>On April 30, 2017, <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> reported that Apple had <a href="/wiki/Cash_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Cash reserve">cash reserves</a> of $250 billion,<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591">[591]</a></sup> officially confirmed by Apple as specifically $256.8 billion a few days later.<sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-592">[592]</a></sup></p><p>As of August 3, 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_corporations_by_market_capitalization" class="mw-redirect" title="List of corporations by market capitalization">largest publicly traded corporation in the world by market capitalization</a>. On August 2, 2018, Apple became the first publicly traded U.S. company to reach a $1 trillion market value.<sup id="cite_ref-1t-CNBC_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-CNBC-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1t-Guardian_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1t-Guardian-13">[13]</a></sup> Apple was ranked No. 4 on the 2018 <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500"><i>Fortune</i> 500</a> rankings of the largest United States corporations by total revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-593" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-593">[593]</a></sup></p>

<td>265,595

<td>59,531
</td>
<td>365,725
</td>
<td>132,000
</td></tr></tbody></table><h4 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Tax_practices">Tax practices</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Apple_Inc.#Tax_practices" title="Criticism of Apple Inc.">Criticism of Apple Inc. § Tax practices</a>, <a href="/wiki/EU_illegal_State_aid_case_against_Apple_in_Ireland" title="EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland">EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leprechaun_economics" title="Leprechaun economics">Leprechaun economics</a></div>
<p>Apple has created subsidiaries in low-tax places such as <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a> to cut the taxes it pays around the world. According to <i>The New York Times,</i> in the 1980s Apple was among the first tech companies to designate overseas salespeople in high-tax countries in a manner that allowed the company to sell on behalf of low-tax subsidiaries on other continents, sidestepping income taxes. In the late 1980s, Apple was a pioneer of an accounting technique known as the "<a href="/wiki/Double_Irish_with_a_Dutch_sandwich" class="mw-redirect" title="Double Irish with a Dutch sandwich">Double Irish with a Dutch sandwich</a>," which reduces taxes by routing profits through Irish subsidiaries and the Netherlands and then to the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-613" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-613">[613]</a></sup></p><p><a href="/wiki/British_Conservative_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="British Conservative Party">British Conservative Party</a> Member of Parliament <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Elphicke" title="Charlie Elphicke">Charlie Elphicke</a> published research on October 30, 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-614" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-614">[614]</a></sup> which showed that some multinational companies, including Apple Inc., were making billions of pounds of profit in the UK, but were paying an effective tax rate to the UK Treasury of only 3 percent, well below standard <a href="/wiki/Corporation_tax" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporation tax">corporation tax</a>. He followed this research by calling on the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a> <a href="/wiki/George_Osborne" title="George Osborne">George Osborne</a> to force these multinationals, which also included <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Coca-Cola_Company" title="The Coca-Cola Company">The Coca-Cola Company</a>, to state the effective rate of tax they pay on their UK revenues. Elphicke also said that government contracts should be withheld from multinationals who do not pay their fair share of UK tax.<sup id="cite_ref-615" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-615">[615]</a></sup></p><p>Apple Inc. claims to be the single largest taxpayer to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">Department of the Treasury</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States of America</a> with an <a href="/wiki/Tax_rate" title="Tax rate">effective tax rate</a> of approximately of 26% as of the second quarter of the Apple <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a> 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-616" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-616">[616]</a></sup> In an interview with the German newspaper FAZ in October 2017, Tim Cook stated, that Apple is the biggest taxpayer worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-617" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-617">[617]</a></sup></p><p>In 2015, <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> reported that Apple had earnings abroad of $54.4 billion which were untaxed by the <a href="/wiki/IRS" class="mw-redirect" title="IRS">IRS</a> of the United States. Under U.S. tax law governed by the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Code" title="Internal Revenue Code">IRC</a>, corporations don't pay income tax on overseas profits unless the profits are repatriated into the United States and as such Apple argues that to benefit its <a href="/wiki/Shareholder" title="Shareholder">shareholders</a> it will leave it overseas until a repatriation holiday or comprehensive tax reform takes place in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-618" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-618">[618]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619">[619]</a></sup></p><p>On July 12, 2016 the <a href="/wiki/Central_Statistics_Office_(Ireland)" title="Central Statistics Office (Ireland)">Central Statistics Office of Ireland</a> announced that 2015 Irish <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a> had grown by 26.3%, and 2015 Irish <a href="/wiki/GNP" class="mw-redirect" title="GNP">GNP</a> had grown by 18.7%.<sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620">[620]</a></sup> The figures attracted international scorn, and were labelled by Nobel-prize winning economist, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Krugman" title="Paul Krugman">Paul Krugman</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Leprechaun_economics" title="Leprechaun economics">leprechaun economics</a>. It was not until 2018 that Irish economists could definitively prove that the 2015 growth was due to Apple restructuring its controversial <a href="/wiki/Double_Irish" class="mw-redirect" title="Double Irish">double Irish</a> subsidiaries (Apple Sales International), which Apple converted into a new Irish <a href="/wiki/Corporation_tax_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland#Multinational_tax_schemes" title="Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland">capital allowances for intangible assets</a> tax scheme (expires in January 2020). The affair required the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Ireland" title="Central Bank of Ireland">Central Bank of Ireland</a> to create a new measure of Irish economic growth, <a href="/wiki/Modified_gross_national_income" title="Modified gross national income">Modified GNI*</a> to replace Irish GDP, given the distortion of Apple's tax schemes. Irish GDP is 143% of Irish Modified GNI*.
</p><p>On August 30, 2016, after <a href="/wiki/EU_illegal_State_aid_case_against_Apple_in_Ireland" title="EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland">a two-year investigation</a>, the EU Competition Commissioner concluded Apple received "illegal State aid" from Ireland. The EU ordered Apple to pay 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion), plus interest, in unpaid Irish taxes for 2004–2014.<sup id="cite_ref-Apple_13_billion_euros_621-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apple_13_billion_euros-621">[621]</a></sup> It is the largest tax fine in history.<sup id="cite_ref-622" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-622">[622]</a></sup> The Commission found that Apple had benefitted from a private Irish <a href="/wiki/Revenue_Commissioners" title="Revenue Commissioners">Revenue Commissioners</a> tax ruling regarding its double Irish tax structure, Apple Sales International (ASI).<sup id="cite_ref-cliff_623-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cliff-623">[623]</a></sup> Instead of using two companies for its double Irish structure, Apple was given a ruling to split ASI into two internal "branches".<sup id="cite_ref-624" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-624">[624]</a></sup> The Chancellor of <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christian_Kern" title="Christian Kern">Christian Kern</a>, put this decision into perspective by stating that "every <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Viennese</a> cafe, every sausage stand pays more tax in Austria than a multinational corporation".<sup id="cite_ref-625" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-625">[625]</a></sup></p><p>As of April 24, 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Apple agreed to start paying €13 billion in back taxes to the Irish government, the repayments will be held in an escrow account while Apple and the Irish government continue their appeals in EU courts.<sup id="cite_ref-626" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-626">[626]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Board_of_directors">Board of directors</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">See also: <a href="/wiki/Category:Directors_of_Apple_Inc." title="Category:Directors of Apple Inc.">Category:Directors of Apple Inc.</a>.</div>
<p>As of October 26, 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the following individuals sit on the <a href="/wiki/Board_of_directors" title="Board of directors">board</a> of Apple Inc.<sup id="cite_ref-aaplLeadership_627-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaplLeadership-627">[627]</a></sup></p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Arthur_D._Levinson" title="Arthur D. Levinson">Arthur D. Levinson</a> (chairman)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> (executive director and CEO)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/James_A._Bell" title="James A. Bell">James A. Bell</a> (non-executive director)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a> (non-executive director)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Andrea_Jung" title="Andrea Jung">Andrea Jung</a> (non-executive director)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Sugar" title="Ronald Sugar">Ronald Sugar</a> (non-executive director)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Susan_Wagner" title="Susan Wagner">Susan Wagner</a> (non-executive director)</li></ul><h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Executive_management">Executive management</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">See also: <a href="/wiki/Category:Apple_Inc._executives" title="Category:Apple Inc. executives">Category:Apple Inc. executives</a>.</div>
<p>As of March 29, 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Apple_Inc.&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the management of Apple Inc. includes:<sup id="cite_ref-aaplLeadership_627-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaplLeadership-627">[627]</a></sup></p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Tim_Cook" title="Tim Cook">Tim Cook</a> (CEO)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Luca_Maestri" title="Luca Maestri">Luca Maestri</a> (senior vice president and CFO)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jeff_Williams_(Apple)" title="Jeff Williams (Apple)">Jeff Williams</a> (chief operating officer (COO))</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jony_Ive" title="Jony Ive">Jonathan Ive, KBE</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chief_design_officer" title="Chief design officer">chief design officer</a> (CDO)) (outgoing)<sup id="cite_ref-628" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-628">[628]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-629" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-629">[629]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Katherine_L._Adams" title="Katherine L. Adams">Katherine L. Adams</a> (senior vice president and general counsel)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Eddy_Cue" title="Eddy Cue">Eddy Cue</a> (senior vice president – internet software and services)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Craig_Federighi" title="Craig Federighi">Craig Federighi</a> (senior vice president – software engineering)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Giannandrea" title="John Giannandrea">John Giannandrea</a> (senior vice president – machine learning and AI strategy)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Deirdre_O%27Brien" title="Deirdre O'Brien">Deirdre O'Brien</a> (senior vice president – <a href="/wiki/Apple_Store" title="Apple Store">retail</a> and people)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dan_Riccio" title="Dan Riccio">Dan Riccio</a> (senior vice president – hardware engineering)</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Johny_Srouji" title="Johny Srouji">Johny Srouji</a> (senior vice president – hardware technologies)</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sabih_Khan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sabih Khan (page does not exist)">Sabih Khan</a> (senior vice president – operations)</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Steven_Dowling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steven Dowling (page does not exist)">Steven Dowling</a> (vice president – communications)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lisa_P._Jackson" title="Lisa P. Jackson">Lisa P. Jackson</a> (vice president – environment, policy, and social initiatives)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Isabel_Ge_Mahe" title="Isabel Ge Mahe">Isabel Ge Mahe</a> (vice president and managing director – Greater China)</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tor_Myhren&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tor Myhren (page does not exist)">Tor Myhren</a> (vice president – marketing communications)</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrian_Perica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adrian Perica (page does not exist)">Adrian Perica</a> (vice president – corporate development)</li></ul><h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Litigation">Litigation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc._litigation" title="Apple Inc. litigation">Apple Inc. litigation</a></div>
<p>Apple has been a participant in various legal proceedings and claims since it began operation.<sup id="cite_ref-630" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-630">[630]</a></sup> In particular, Apple is known for and promotes itself as actively and aggressively enforcing its intellectual property interests. Some litigation examples include <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_v._Samsung" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple v. Samsung">Apple v. Samsung</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_v._Microsoft" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple v. Microsoft">Apple v. Microsoft</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Motorola_Mobility_v._Apple_Inc." title="Motorola Mobility v. Apple Inc.">Motorola Mobility v. Apple Inc.</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps_v._Apple_Computer" class="mw-redirect" title="Apple Corps v. Apple Computer">Apple Corps v. Apple Computer</a></i>. Apple has also had to defend itself against charges on numerous occasions of violating intellectual property rights. Most have been dismissed in the courts as <a href="/wiki/Shell_corporation" title="Shell corporation">shell companies</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Patent_troll" title="Patent troll">patent trolls</a>, with no evidence of actual use of <a href="/wiki/Patent" title="Patent">patents</a> in question.<sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631">[631]</a></sup> On December 21, 2016, Nokia announced that in the U.S. and Germany, it has filed a suit against Apple, claiming that the latter's products infringe on Nokia's patents.<sup id="cite_ref-632" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-632">[632]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-633" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-633">[633]</a></sup> Most recently, in November 2017, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_International_Trade_Commission" title="United States International Trade Commission">United States International Trade Commission</a> announced an investigation into allegations of patent infringement in regards to Apple's remote desktop technology; Aqua Connect, a company that builds remote desktop software, has claimed that Apple infringed on two of its patents.<sup id="cite_ref-634" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-634">[634]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Privacy_stance">Privacy stance</span></h3>
<p>Apple has a notable pro-privacy stance, actively making privacy-conscious features and settings part of its conferences, promotional campaigns, and public image.<sup id="cite_ref-635" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-635">[635]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-636" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-636">[636]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-637" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-637">[637]</a></sup> With its <a href="/wiki/IOS_8" title="IOS 8">iOS 8</a> mobile operating system in 2014, the company started encryption all contents of iOS devices through users' passcodes, making it impossible for the company to provide customer data to law enforcement requests seeking such information.<sup id="cite_ref-638" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-638">[638]</a></sup> With the popularity rise of cloud storage solutions, Apple began a technique in 2016 to do <a href="/wiki/Deep_learning" title="Deep learning">deep learning</a> scans for facial data in photos on the user's local device and encrypting the content before uploading it to Apple's <a href="/wiki/ICloud" title="ICloud">iCloud</a> storage system.<sup id="cite_ref-639" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-639">[639]</a></sup> It also introduced "differential privacy", a way to collect crowdsourced data from many users, while keeping individual users anonymous, in a system that <i><a href="/wiki/Wired_(website)" class="mw-redirect" title="Wired (website)">Wired</a></i> described as "trying to learn as much as possible about a group while learning as little as possible about any individual in it".<sup id="cite_ref-640" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-640">[640]</a></sup> Users are explicitly asked if they want to participate, and can actively opt-in or opt-out.<sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641">[641]</a></sup></p><p>However, Apple aids law enforcement in criminal investigations by providing iCloud backups of users' devices,<sup id="cite_ref-642" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-642">[642]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-643" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-643">[643]</a></sup> and the company's commitment to privacy has been questioned by its efforts to promote <a href="/wiki/Biometrics" title="Biometrics">biometric authentication</a> technology in its newer <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a> models, which don't have the same level of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Constitution">constitutional privacy</a> as a passcode in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-644" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-644">[644]</a></sup></p>
<h3 class="in-block"><span class="mw-headline" id="Charitable_causes">Charitable causes</span></h3>
<p>Apple is a partner of <a href="/wiki/Product_Red" title="Product Red">(PRODUCT)RED</a>, a fundraising campaign for <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">AIDS</a> charity. In November 2014, Apple arranged for all <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">App Store</a> revenue in a two-week period to go to the fundraiser,<sup id="cite_ref-645" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-645">[645]</a></sup> generating more than US$20 million,<sup id="cite_ref-646" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-646">[646]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-647" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-647">[647]</a></sup> and in March 2017, it released an <a href="/wiki/IPhone_7" title="IPhone 7">iPhone 7</a> with a red color finish.<sup id="cite_ref-648" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-648">[648]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-649" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-649">[649]</a></sup></p><p>Apple contributes financially to fundraisers in times of natural disasters. In November 2012, it donated $2.5 million to the <a href="/wiki/American_Red_Cross" title="American Red Cross">American Red Cross</a> to aid relief efforts after <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-650" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-650">[650]</a></sup> and in 2017 it donated $5 million to relief efforts for both <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">Hurricane Irma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Harvey" title="Hurricane Harvey">Hurricane Harvey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-651" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-651">[651]</a></sup> as well as for the <a href="/wiki/2017_Central_Mexico_earthquake" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 Central Mexico earthquake">2017 Central Mexico earthquake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-652" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-652">[652]</a></sup> The company has also used its <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a> platform to encourage donations, including, but not limited to, help the American Red Cross in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-653" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-653">[653]</a></sup> followed by similar procedure in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 Japan earthquake</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-654" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-654">[654]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan" title="Typhoon Haiyan">Typhoon Haiyan</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> in November 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-655" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-655">[655]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis" title="European migrant crisis">European migrant crisis</a> in September 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-656" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-656">[656]</a></sup> Apple emphasizes that it does not incur any processing or other fees for iTunes donations, sending 100% of the payments directly to relief efforts, though it also acknowledges that the Red Cross does not receive any personal information on the users donating and that the payments may not be tax deductible.<sup id="cite_ref-657" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-657">[657]</a></sup></p><p>On April 14, 2016, Apple and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a> (WWF) announced that they have engaged in a partnership to, "help protect life on our planet." Apple released a special page in the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" title="App Store (iOS)">iTunes App Store</a>, Apps for Earth. In the arrangement, Apple has committed that through April 24, WWF will receive 100% of the proceeds from the applications participating in the App Store via both the purchases of any paid apps and the In-App Purchases. Apple and WWF's Apps for Earth campaign raised more than $8 million in total proceeds to support WWF's conservation work. WWF announced the results at WWDC 2016 in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-658" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-658">[658]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-659" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-659">[659]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-660" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-660">[660]</a></sup></p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_coronavirus_pandemic" title="2019–20 coronavirus pandemic">2019–20 coronavirus pandemic</a> outbreak, Apple's CEO Cook announced that the company will be donating "millions" of masks to health workers in the United States and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-661" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-661">[661]</a></sup></p>
</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(5)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism_and_controversies">Criticism and controversies</span></h2><section class="mf-section-5 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-5">
<table class="box-Summarize plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span"><b>This section should include a better summary of <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Apple_Inc." title="Criticism of Apple Inc.">Criticism of Apple Inc.</a>.</b> See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">Wikipedia:Summary style</a> for information on how to properly incorporate it into this article's main text.  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">November 2017</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Apple_Inc." title="Criticism of Apple Inc.">Criticism of Apple Inc.</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prism-slide-8.jpg" class="image"><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Prism-slide-8.jpg/220px-Prism-slide-8.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="525"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 220px;height: 165px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Prism-slide-8.jpg/220px-Prism-slide-8.jpg" data-alt="" data-width="220" data-height="165" data-class="thumbimage"> </span></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Prism-slide-8.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)" title="PRISM (surveillance program)">PRISM</a>: a <a href="/wiki/Clandestine_operation" title="Clandestine operation">clandestine</a> <a href="/wiki/Global_surveillance" title="Global surveillance">surveillance</a> program under which the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">NSA</a> collects user data from companies like Facebook and Apple.<sup id="cite_ref-662" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-662">[662]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Apple has been criticized for alleged <a href="/wiki/Business_ethics" title="Business ethics">unethical business practices</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Anti-competitive_practices" title="Anti-competitive practices">anti-competitive behavior</a>, rash litigation,<sup id="cite_ref-663" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-663">[663]</a></sup> dubious tax tactics, production methods involving the use of <a href="/wiki/Sweatshop" title="Sweatshop">sweatshop</a> labor,<sup id="cite_ref-sweatshop1_664-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sweatshop1-664">[664]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sweatshop2_665-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sweatshop2-665">[665]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sweatshop3_666-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sweatshop3-666">[666]</a></sup> customer service issues involving allegedly misleading warranties and insufficient <a href="/wiki/Data_security" title="Data security">data security</a>, and its products' environmental footprint. Critics have claimed that Apple products combine stolen and/or purchased designs that Apple claims are its original creations.<sup id="cite_ref-667" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-667">[667]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-668" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-668">[668]</a></sup> It has been criticized for its alleged collaboration with the U.S. surveillance program <a href="/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)" title="PRISM (surveillance program)">PRISM</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-669" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-669">[669]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-670" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-670">[670]</a></sup></p><p>Apple's issues regarding music over the years include those with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> regarding iTunes,<sup id="cite_ref-671" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-671">[671]</a></sup> trouble over updating the Spotify app on Apple devices<sup id="cite_ref-672" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-672">[672]</a></sup> and collusion with record labels.<sup id="cite_ref-673" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-673">[673]</a></sup></p><p>Apple has faced scrutiny for its tax practices, including using a <a href="/wiki/Double_Irish_arrangement" title="Double Irish arrangement">Double Irish Arrangement</a> to reduce the amount of taxes it pays.<sup id="cite_ref-674" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-674">[674]</a></sup> A 2013 US Senate report claimed that Apple hadn't paid corporate taxes for five years due to its deals with the Irish government.<sup id="cite_ref-675" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-675">[675]</a></sup> In 2016, the European Union ordered Apple to pay a fine for its actions.<sup id="cite_ref-676" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-676">[676]</a></sup></p><p>In 2018–19, Apple <a href="/wiki/Nvidia#Apple/NVIDIA_web_driver_controversy" title="Nvidia">faced criticism</a> for its failure to approve <a href="/wiki/NVIDIA" class="mw-redirect" title="NVIDIA">NVIDIA</a> <a href="/wiki/Device_driver" title="Device driver">web drivers</a> for <a href="/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit" title="Graphics processing unit">GPU</a> installed on legacy <a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro" title="Mac Pro">Mac Pro</a> machines up to <a href="/wiki/Mac_Pro#1st_generation" title="Mac Pro">mid 2012 5,1</a> running <a href="/wiki/MacOS_Mojave" title="MacOS Mojave">macOS Mojave</a> 10.14. Without Apple approved NVIDIA web drivers, Apple users are faced with replacing their NVIDIA cards with a competing supported brand, such as <a href="/wiki/AMD_Radeon" class="mw-redirect" title="AMD Radeon">AMD Radeon</a> from the list recommended by Apple.
</p><p>In June 2019, Apple issued a recall for its 2015 MacBook Pro Retina 15" affecting 432,000 units after reports of batteries catching fire. The recall was criticized as waiting times for replacements were up to 3 weeks and the company didn't provide alternative replacements or repair options.<sup id="cite_ref-677" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-677">[677]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-678" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-678">[678]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-679" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-679">[679]</a></sup></p><p>Ireland's Data Protection Commission in Ireland also launched a privacy investigation to examine whether Apple complied with the EU's <a href="/wiki/GDPR" class="mw-redirect" title="GDPR">GDPR</a> law following an investigation into how the company processes personal data with targeted ads on its platform.<sup id="cite_ref-680" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-680">[680]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-681" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-681">[681]</a></sup></p><p>In July 2019, following a campaign by the "<a href="/wiki/Electronics_right_to_repair" title="Electronics right to repair">right to repair</a>" movement, challenging Apple's tech repair restrictions on devices, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission" title="Federal Trade Commission">FTC</a> held a workshop to establish the framework of a future nationwide Right to Repair rule. The movement argues Apple is preventing consumers from legitimately fixing their devices at local repair shops which is having a negative impact on consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-682" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-682">[682]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-683" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-683">[683]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-684" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-684">[684]</a></sup></p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">United States Department of Justice</a> also began a review of big tech firms to establish whether they could be unlawfully stifling competition in a broad <a href="/wiki/Antitrust" class="mw-redirect" title="Antitrust">antitrust</a> probe in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-685" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-685">[685]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-686" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-686">[686]</a></sup></p><p>In December 2019, a report found that the iPhone 11 Pro continues tracking location and collecting user data even after users have disabled location services. In response, an Apple engineer said the Location Services icon "appears for system services that do not have a switch in settings."<sup id="cite_ref-687" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-687">[687]</a></sup></p><p>In January 2020, US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> slammed Apple for refusing to unlock two <a href="/wiki/IPhones" class="mw-redirect" title="IPhones">iPhones</a> of a Saudi national,  Mohammed Saeed Alshamrani, who shot and killed three American sailors and injured eight others in the <a href="/wiki/Naval_air_station" title="Naval air station">Naval air base</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Naval_Air_Station_Pensacola_shooting" title="Naval Air Station Pensacola shooting">Pensacola shooting</a> was declared an "act of terrorism" by the FBI, but Apple denied to crack the phones citing its data privacy policy.<sup id="cite_ref-688" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-688">[688]</a></sup></p><p>On 16 March 2020, France fined Apple <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">€</a> 1.1bn for colluding with two wholesalers to stifle competition and keep prices high by handicapping independent resellers. The arrangement created aligned prices for Apple products such as iPads and personal computers for about half the French retail market. According to the French regulators, the abuses occurred between 2005 and 2017, but were first discovered after a complaint by an independent reseller, eBizcuss, in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-689" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-689">[689]</a></sup></p>
</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(6)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2><section class="mf-section-6 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-6">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Apple_Inc._media_events" title="List of Apple Inc. media events">List of Apple Inc. media events</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</a></li></ul></section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(7)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2><section class="mf-section-7 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-7">

<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Rivas, Teresa. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.barrons.com/articles/ranking-the-big-four-internet-stocks-google-is-no-1-apple-comes-in-last-1503412102">"Ranking The Big Four Tech Stocks: Google Is No. 1, Apple Comes In Last"</a>. <i>www.barrons.com</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181228082808/https://www.barrons.com/articles/ranking-the-big-four-internet-stocks-google-is-no-1-apple-comes-in-last-1503412102">Archived</a> from the original on December 28, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Ritholtz, Barry (October 31, 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2017-10-31/the-big-four-of-technology">"The Big Four of Technology"</a>. <i>Bloomberg L.P</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190626024146/https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2017-10-31/the-big-four-of-technology">Archived</a> from the original on June 26, 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">December 27,</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg+L.P.&amp;rft.atitle=The+Big+Four+of+Technology&amp;rft.date=2017-10-31&amp;rft.aulast=Ritholtz&amp;rft.aufirst=Barry&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fopinion%2Farticles%2F2017-10-31%2Fthe-big-four-of-technology&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AApple+Inc." class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r935243608"></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/GAFA">"What is GAFA (the Big Four)? - Definition from WhatIs.com"</a>. <i>WhatIs.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">March 5,</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=WhatIs.com&amp;rft.atitle=What+is+GAFA+%28the+Big+Four%29%3F+-+Definition+from+WhatIs.com&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwhatis.techtarget.com%2Fdefinition%2FGAFA&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AApple+Inc." class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r935243608"></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Cowin-366"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Cowin_366-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Cowin_366-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Cowin_366-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Cowin, E. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://stars.library.ucf.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3024&amp;context=etd">"The evolution of U.S. corporate logos a semiotic analysis"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-556"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-556">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/global-warming/click-clean/#report">"ClickClean"</a>. <i>Click Clean</i>. <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-557"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-557">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.apple.com/environment/">"Environment"</a>. <li id="cite_note-558"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-558">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Cardwell, Diane (August 23, 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/24/business/energy-environment/as-energy-use-rises-corporations-turn-to-their-own-green-utility-sources.html">"Apple Becomes a Green Energy Supplier, With Itself as Customer"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161129164413/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/24/business/energy-environment/as-energy-use-rises-corporations-turn-to-their-own-green-utility-sources.html">Archived</a> from the original on November 29, 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">December 30,</span> 2016</span>. <q>clean power often does not flow directly to their facilities. They typically buy the renewable energy in amounts to match what they draw from the grid. They're actually getting power from their local utility, which may be coal</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Apple+Becomes+a+Green+Energy+Supplier%2C+With+Itself+as+Customer&amp;rft.date=2016-08-23&amp;rft.aulast=Cardwell&amp;rft.aufirst=Diane&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2016%2F08%2F24%2Fbusiness%2Fenergy-environment%2Fas-energy-use-rises-corporations-turn-to-their-own-green-utility-sources.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AApple+Inc." class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r935243608"></span>

<li id="cite_note-559"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-559">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Cole, Nicki Lisa (August 5, 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/32208-why-is-apple-lying-about-powering-its-data-centers-with-renewable-energy">"Why Is Apple Lying About Powering Its Data Centers With Renewable Energy?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Truthout" title="Truthout">Truthout</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160630060630/http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/32208-why-is-apple-lying-about-powering-its-data-centers-with-renewable-energy">Archived</a> from the original on June 30, 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">December 30,</span> 2016</span>. <q>Apple buys renewable energy certificates to offset its reliance on Duke's dirty energy. ..purchasing offsets is not the same as actually powering something with renewable energy</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Truthout&amp;rft.atitle=Why+Is+Apple+Lying+About+Powering+Its+Data+Centers+With+Renewable+Energy%3F&amp;rft.date=2015-08-05&amp;rft.aulast=Cole&amp;rft.aufirst=Nicki+Lisa&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.truth-out.org%2Fnews%2Fitem%2F32208-why-is-apple-lying-about-powering-its-data-centers-with-renewable-energy&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AApple+Inc." class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r935243608"></span>

</section><h2 class="section-heading" onclick="javascript:mfTempOpenSection(9)"><div class="mw-ui-icon mw-ui-icon-element indicator mw-ui-icon-small mw-ui-icon-flush-left"></div><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2><section class="mf-section-9 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-9">

<li><noscript><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/16px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" data-file-width="256" data-file-height="256"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 16px;height: 16px;" data-src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/16px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png" data-alt="" data-width="16" data-height="16" data-srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/24px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/32px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 2x"> </span> Geographic data related to <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/way/33463538">Apple Inc. headquarters</a> at <a href="/wiki/OpenStreetMap" title="OpenStreetMap">OpenStreetMap</a></li></ul>
